{{redirect|Allers|people named Allers|Allers (surname)|other uses of Aller|Aller (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox company | name = Aller Media | logo = Aller Media logo.png | logo_size = 120 | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = 1873 |founder = [[Carl Aller]] | location_city = [[Copenhagen]] | location_country = [[Denmark]] | key_people = [[Bettina Aller]] | industry = [[Mass Media]] | revenue = | net_income = | num_employees = | homepage = [http://www.aller.dk/English.aspx www.aller.dk] }} [[Image:Aller Media, Copenhagen.jpg|thumb|250px|The Aller building on [[Havneholmen]] in [[Copenhagen]] ]]
'''Aller Media''' is a [[magazine]] publisher in the [[Nordic countries]], headquartered in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aller.dk/English/About%20Aller.aspx|title=About Aller|work=Aller|year=2012|accessdate=9 February 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207032406/http://www.aller.dk/English/About%20Aller.aspx|archive-date=7 February 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It publishes ''Elle'', ''Cafe'', ''[[Familie Journalen]]'', ''[[Femina (Denmark)|Femina]]'', ''Allers'' and ''Se og Hør''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.magpeople.com/w/?p=1018|title=Aller Magazine: magPeople|work=magPeople|year=2012|accessdate=9 February 2012}}</ref>
==History== Aller Media was founded in [[Copenhagen]] in 1873 by [[Carl Aller]] and his wife Laura Aller.<ref>{{cite web|title=Carl Allers Etablissement A/S|url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history/Ca-Ch/Carl-Allers-Etablissement-A-S.html|work=Reference for Business|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> It expanded into [[Sweden]] and [[Norway]] in the 1890s and into [[Finland]] in 1992. In August, 2009, Aller Press A/S changed its name to Aller Media A/S.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.aller.dk/Presse/Presse%20og%20selskabsmeddelelser/Aller%20skifter%20navn%20til%20Aller%20media.aspx |title=Information about change of name from the company website (in Danish) |access-date=31 October 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090707005556/http://www.aller.dk/Presse/Presse%20og%20selskabsmeddelelser/Aller%20skifter%20navn%20til%20Aller%20media.aspx |archive-date=7 July 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The same year Aller moved into a new headquarters at [[Havneholmen]]. The building is designed by [[PLH Architects]].
==Magazines and newspapers== Aller's publications are among the most read in Sweden. It publishes 34 magazines every month which are read by over 4 million people including the best selling magazine in Sweden as of 2004, the TV Guide ''Se & Hör'', which is published in Norway and Denmark as ''[[Se og Hør (Norway)|Se og Hør]]''.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
''Allers'' magazine is distributed in Norway and Sweden for the mature female market group. It traces its origins from the [[Denmark|Danish]] weekly ''[[Familie Journalen|Illustreret Familie-Journal]]'', founded in 1877 by Carl Aller.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Oskar Bandle|author2=Kurt Braunmuller|author3=Ernst-Hakon Jahr|author4=Allan Karker |author5=Hans-Peter Naumann|author6=Ulf Teleman|title=The Nordic Languages 2: An International Handbook of the History of the North Germanic Languages|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6b7WwBC5tRAC&pg=PA1487|accessdate=24 November 2014|year=2005|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-017149-5|page=1487}}</ref> In 1894 it moved base to [[Helsingborg]] and changed its name to the ''Allers Family-Journal''. In 1959 the name was changed to ''Allers Family Journal'', which in 1968 was shortened to ''Allers''. The original magazine was a pioneer in including crosswords and cartoons in magazines in Sweden. ''Allers'' is the oldest magazine still in circulation in Norway where it has been published since 1897.
In June 2013, Aller Media bought ''[[Dagbladet]]'' with online products from Berner Gruppen for reportedly about 300 million [[Norwegian kroner]].<ref>Eric B. Utheim and Line Midtsjø (21 June 2013): [http://e24.no/media/haaper-aa-faa-fortsette-paa-dagbladet-fronten/20384659 Håper å få fortsette på Dagbladet-fronten] {{no icon}} [[E24 Næringsliv|E24]], Retrieved 21 June 2013</ref> In February 2014 the company acquired several Finnish [[Women's magazines|women's]] and lifestyle magazines from [[Bonnier Group]], namely ''[[Costume (magazine)|Costume]]'', ''Divaani'' and ''[[Olivia (magazine)|Olivia]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bonnier Publications sells Finnish lifestyle magazines|url=http://www.bonnier.com/news-press/News/2014/February/Bonnier-Publications-sells-Finnish-lifestyle-magazines/|accessdate=6 April 2015|work=Bonnier Group|date=7 February 2014}}</ref>
In Sweden, editorial offices are today (2009) located in [[Stockholm]], [[Göteborg]], [[Helsingborg]] and [[Malmö]].<ref>[http://www.mynewsdesk.com/se/pressroom/picsearch/pressrelease/view/largest-nordic-publishing-house-allers-foerlag-launches-web-tv-with-picsearch-magazine-fiskejournalen-releases-professional-fishing-video-channel-299341 Mynewsdesk.com]</ref>
In 2015 Aller Media launched ''L33t Magazine'', an online [[English language]] publication focusing on [[esports]] and competitive [[video game]]s. The team is based in [[Copenhagen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://1337mag.com/meet-the-team|title=Meet the Team|website=L33t Magazine|accessdate=1 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151108235202/http://1337mag.com/meet-the-team|archive-date=8 November 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The company appeared to have halted publication of new articles on the ''L33t Magazine'' website after the end of 2015.
==See also== *[[List of Norwegian magazines]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.aller.dk/english/about-aller/ Official site in English]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Australia Calls | image = | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Raymond Longford]] | producer = [[Charles Cozens Spencer]] | writer = J. Barr
C.A. Jeffries | narrator = | starring = [[Lottie Lyell]] | music = | cinematography = [[Arthur Higgins]]
[[Tasman Higgins]]
[[Ernest Higgins]] | editing = Ernest Higgins | studio = Spencer's Pictures | distributor = | released = 19 July 1913"Raymond Longford", ''Cinema Papers'', January 1974 p51 | runtime = 4,000 feet | country = Australia | language = [[Silent film]]
English intertitles | budget = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Australia Calls''''' is a 1913 Australian [[silent film]] directed by [[Raymond Longford]] about the fictitious invasion of Australia by an unnamed Asian country. The movie is not to be confused with Longford's 1923 picture ''[[Australia Calls (1923 film)|Australia Calls]]'' and is considered a [[lost film]]. Longford later claimed the film was the first Australian movie to have mass extras (from Sydney's Chinatown) and feature model photography, as well as being the first film in the world to show wireless. Film historians have said "the scale and blatant progpaganda of [the film]... made it the least typical of Longford's thirty narrative films".Graham Shirley and Brian Adams, ''Australian Cinema: The First Eighty Years'', Currency Press 1989 p 32 ==Synopsis== The film begins with a prologue, 'The Warning', showing a Sydney horse race, then a football match in front of thousands of spectators. Living on an outback station, Beatrice Evans ([[Lottie Lyell]]) rejects the advances of a suitor. An unnamed Asian country lands 20,000 troops (called "Mongolians") on the New South Wales coast, and Australia issues a call to arms, mobilising its forces. The invading army attacks Sydney, setting buildings on fire and taking over the Min, Treasury Building and wireless telegraph station. The rejected suitor turns traitor and Beatrice is captured by the enemy. However she is rescued by plane with the help of aviator William E. Hart and the Australians are victorious.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article10363264 "AMUSEMENTS." ''The Mercury (Hobart)'' 26 Feb 1914: 3] A contemporary review said "the synopsis contains scenes of Australians at play, at the races, at football, the call to arms, the burning of Sydney, the enemy in possession, Australian mobilising, the capture of the wireless station, treachery, in the hands of the enemy, Australian bushmen rallying, tapping the overhead telegraph wires, the charge of the lancers, and ride for life, William E. Hart (Australia's aviator) to the rescue."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article50745527 "PRINCESS THEATRE." ''Examiner (Launceston)'' 17 Feb 1914: 6] ==Cast== *[[Lottie Lyell]] as Beatrice Evans *Frank Phillips as Evans *Alfred O'Shea *George Wilkins *William E. Hart as aviator *Andrew Warr as Asian commander ==Production== The movie was written by two journalists from the magazine ''[[The Bulletin]]'' and sought to exploit Australia's fear of the [[Yellow Peril]]. Filming was done with the assistance of the Australian Defence Department and took over a year to complete, including model work to convey the burning of Sydney.Graham Shirley and Brian Adams, ''Australian Cinema: the First Eighty Years'', Currency Press, 1989 p 32{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article128376848 |title=It All Began With a Feature Movie On The Kelly Gang. |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)|The News]] |location=Adelaide |date=16 November 1946 |accessdate=20 February 2014 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} The cast includes early Australian aviator William Edward Hart, who made the first cross-country flight in [[New South Wales]], and later tenor Alfred O'Shea. [[Ernest Higgins]] shot some aerial photography for the film on a flight with Hart. Scenes involving Hart were shot at Richmond.[http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/hart-william-ewart-6592 William Ewart Hart] at ''[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0002649|title=Australia Calls}} *[https://archive.is/20121126232521/http://colsearch.nfsa.gov.au/nfsa/search/display/display.w3p;adv=;group=;groupequals=;holdingType=;page=0;parentid=;query=Id:343326;querytype=;rec=0;resCount=10 ''Australia Calls''] at [[National Film and Sound Archive]] {{Raymond Longford}} [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:1913 films]] [[Category:Australian drama films]] [[Category:Australian silent feature films]] [[Category:Australian black-and-white films]] [[Category:Films directed by Raymond Longford]] [[Category:Lost Australian films]]

[[File:Begleri moderne.JPG|thumb|An example of modern begleri]] '''Begleri''' ([[Greek language|Greek]]: μπεγλέρι) is a small [[skill toy]] consisting of one or more beads at either end of a short string or fine chain. The toy can be flipped and twirled around the fingers to perform tricks. Begleri originated in Greece, and originally derived from the Greek rosary or [[komboloi]], which serve the function of worry beads, and are often flipped around to pass the time or keep the hands busy. While komboloi have beads forming a closed circle, begleri beads are threaded on an open strand, usually in a symmetrical formation, with equal weighting at either end.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of Komboloi|url=http://www.kombologadiko.gr/historyen.html|website=Kombologatiko|accessdate=7 April 2016}}</ref> Begleri come in many forms, consisting of semi-precious stone or metal beads. They can be similar in form to the percussion instrument [[kashaka]], but are much smaller in size.
== Modern Begleri revival == Historically, begleri was associated with the Greek mangas subculture, and the rebetiko style of music, popular until the 1960s. In recent years, begleri has grown in popularity outside of Greece, as a skill toy and everyday carry item. This has led to a proliferation of begleri designs and styles, using all manner of modern materials. The recent uptick in interest among collectors and skill toy enthusiasts dates back to at least the early 2010s, when it began gaining popularity on hobbyist sites. As the popularity grew in online forums and social media, different styles of play began to emerge. A wide range of different styles of play and categories of tricks have developed, many of which can only be performed with relatively long-stringed begleri, termed "long game" by enthusiasts.
== Modern types of Begleri == Modern begleri as a skill toy has gained popularity with many people across the world. Due to the nature of play, begleri have shifted from the traditional ornate beads to simpler performance oriented beads. Two common begleri types are [[Monkey's fist|monkey-fist]] "beads", and solid type beads. Monkey-fist begleri are commonly made by people beginning to practice "slinging" the common term for begleri manipulation. Solid type beads are becoming more and more common, and there a few companies that are developing new geometries of beads based on feedback from consumers.
== In popular culture == Axel Schönberg, a character in [[John M. Green]]'s thriller, The Trusted,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/books/the-trusted-20130406-2hd2t.html#ixzz2Q6yOtGvj|title=The Trusted|last=Dobbin|first=Winsor|date=2013-04-07|work=|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-05|via=}}</ref> is almost always twirling a set of gold begleri in his fingers.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox ethnic group |group= Bahand |population = 33,000 |popplace = • India • Nepal |langs = • [[Urdu language|Urdu]] • [[Hindi language|Hindi]] • [[Kashmiri language|Kashmiri]] • [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] |rels= [[Islam]] |related= [[Naqqal]] }}
'''Bahānds''' ([[Devanagari]]: भांड, [[Urdu]]: بھانڈ, [[Gurmukhi]]: ਭਾਂਡ) are the traditional folk entertainers of [[India]], [[Bangladesh]], and [[Nepal]]. In India and Nepal, the Bahand are now an [[endogamy|endogamous]] Muslim community, which is no longer involved in their traditional occupation of folk entertainment.<ref name="ref96mabaj">{{Citation | title=History of Indian theatre | author=Manohar Laxman Varadpande | publisher=Abhinav Publications, 1992 | isbn=978-81-7017-278-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6ZrjC24PuDQC | quote=''... The most popular of the medieval folk entertainers who still linger on the Indian scene are the Bahands. In [[Sanskrit]] Bahand means jester ... Bahands were patronised by the people and royalty alike ... small skits with extempore jokes, humour laced with social criticism ...''}}</ref> They include actors, dancers, minstrels, storytellers and impressionists.<ref name="ref25fayum">{{Citation | title=Supplement to the glossary of Indian terms | author= Henry Miers Elliot | publisher=N.H. Longden, 1845 | isbn= | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ThnNjANUtyoC | quote=''... Those also are called Bahand who without reference to caste follow the occupation of singing, dancing, and assuming disguises ...''}}</ref><ref name="ref20pumic">{{Citation | title=The world encyclopedia of contemporary theatre, Volume 3 | author=Don Rubin | publisher=Taylor & Francis, 2001 | isbn=978-0-415-26087-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=maGU4ziPQJQC | quote=''... one actor goes around collecting money (pay-what-you-can) from the audience ... In the swang tradition is the naqal of Punjab: farcical in nature, it relies heavily on improvisation by the naqalchi ... The bahands are itinerant clowns. It is a centuries-old tradition in the villages, and very popular at marriages. It may be a solo performance, or a troupe may have two or three people. Dressed in rustic clothes ...''}}</ref>
Payment for performances is usually voluntary: often, one performer goes around the audience collecting money on a "pay-what-you-can" basis while the others continue to perform.<ref name="ref20pumic"/> While most ''bahands'' belong to families that are engaged in folk entertainment as their hereditary profession, their specific art forms vary greatly by region, community and language. The term ''bahand'' itself can also mean both a specific dramatic story or an entire form/school of drama.
== Bahand of Uttar Pradesh ==
In [[Uttar Pradesh]], the Bahand are an endogamous Muslim community. Their ancestors were employed at the court of the various local rulers as folk entertainers, in particular at the court of the [[Nawabs of Awadh]]. Most Bahand in Uttar Pradesh are no longer involved with folk entertainment. What now binds the community is a sense of stigma attached to the community on account of their ancestral occupation. They are now mainly involved in wage labour; many [[Lucknow]] city are [[Pulled rickshaw|rickshaw]] puller. Little is known about the origin of this community, other than that their ancestors were ''bahands''. The community has been granted [[Other Backward Classes|Other Backward Class]] status, which gives the community some benefits with regards reservation in public sector jobs. They are [[Sunni]] Muslims, and speak [[Urdu]], and rarely dialects of [[Hindi language|Hindi]]. The [[Naqqal]] sub-group has done better, and now prefer the self-designation Kashmiri Shaikh. They are now a community of successful businessmen.<ref>''People of India Uttar Pradesh'' Volume XLII Part One edited by A Hasan & J C Das pages 261 to 262 Manohar Publications</ref>
==Bahand Pather of Kashmir== [[File:Bhand Pather.jpg|thumbnail|Bahand Pather]] ''Bahand Pather'' is a ''bahand'' of the [[Kashmir]] region in which stories commemorating the lives of ''reshis'' (Sufi Sages, both Hindus and Muslims) or more contemporary real or fictional figures are enacted.<ref name="ref31pixup">{{Citation | title=South Asian folklore: an encyclopedia : Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Sri Lanka |author1=Peter J. Claus |author2=Sarah Diamond |author3=Margaret Ann Mills | publisher=Taylor & Francis, 2003 | isbn=978-0-415-93919-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ienxrTPHzzwC | quote=''... At the heart of the form, though, is the broad, farcical playing of the maskharas, or clowns ...''}}</ref> The storylines (or ''pathers'') are often humorous and satirical, and [[farce]] is an essential component of the plays.<ref name="ref31pixup"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.koausa.org/BhandPather/index.html |title= The Bhand Pather of Kashmir}}</ref>
==Naqal of Punjab== ''Naqal'' (mimicry) is a strong ''bahand'' tradition in the Punjab region.<ref name="ref20pumic"/> The ''naqalchi'' (mimic, sometimes called the ''[[bahrupiya]]'') adopts the persona of a well-known person or character and improvises, using satire and farce extensively, to entertain the audience.<ref name="ref20pumic"/>
==The Ustad and jamoora format== The ''ustad-[[jamoora]]'' format (''ustad'' means master in [[Hindustani language|Hindustani]], while ''jamoora'' is an assistant or follower who is usually younger than the ''ustad'') is a popular one in Hindi-speaking regions and involves only two ''bhand'' actors. Usually, the storylines consist of the ''ustad'' tutoring the ''jamoora'' to do or say something, and the ''jamoora'' responding with mechanical obedience with a subtle variation thrown in that creates a strong comical or satirical effect.
==See also== *[[Behrupiya]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox person | name = Bill Cosby in advertising | image = Bill Cosby (2010).jpg | imagesize = | caption = Cosby speaking at [[Riverside Church]], [[New York City]], in 2010. | birth_name = William Henry Cosby Jr. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1937|7|12}} | years_active = | notable_works = [[White Owl]]
[[Jell-O]]
[[Coca-Cola]]
[[Texas Instruments]]
[[E. F. Hutton & Co.]]
[[Kodak]]
[[1990 United States Census]]
[[Crest (toothpaste)|Crest]] | website = http://www.billcosby.com/ }} American comedian [[Bill Cosby]] was a popular spokesperson for advertising from the 1960s{{spaced ndash}}before his first starring television role{{spaced ndash}}until the early 2000s. He started with [[White Owl]] cigars, and later endorsed [[Jell-O]] pudding and gelatin, [[Coca-Cola]] (including [[New Coke]]), [[Texas Instruments]], [[E. F. Hutton & Co.]], [[Kodak]], and the [[1990 United States Census]]. {{As of|2002}}, Cosby held the record for being the longest-serving celebrity spokesperson for a product, through his work with Jell-O. In 2011, he won the President's Award for Contributions to Advertising from the [[Advertising Hall of Fame]]. Cosby was one of the first black people to appear in the United States as an advertising spokesperson. He was known for his appeal to white consumers in the second half of the 20th century, in an industry seen as slow to accept diversity. In spite of making contradictory soft drink pitches and endorsing a disgraced financial company, he continued to be considered effective and believable. In the 1980s, studies found Cosby the "most familiar" and "most persuasive" spokesperson, to the point where Cosby attributed his wealth to these contracts, as opposed to his television series. However, in 2014, allegations of sexual assault significantly damaged Cosby's public image; public opinion polling following the news placed him near the bottom of a list of 3,000 personalities, when rated on trust and effectiveness. Public opinion of him dropped substantially in 2014, by many [[Bill Cosby sexual assault cases|sexual assault accusations]], the earliest of which dates back decades. More than 60 women accused him of [[rape]], [[drug-facilitated sexual assault]], [[sexual battery]], [[child sexual abuse]], and [[sexual misconduct]], although the [[statute of limitations]] had by then expired in nearly all cases. Cosby was found guilty of three counts of [[aggravated indecent assault]] in April 2018, and sentenced to 3 to 10 years in prison in September 2018. ==Personality== {{Quote box |width = 30em |border = 1px |align = left |bgcolor = #c6dbf7 |fontsize = 85% |title_bg = |title_fnt = |title = |quoted=yes |quote = First of all and lastly, I'm good—that's all—I'm good. I don't rewrite their material. I take it and I ''make'' it. |salign = right |source = Cosby attributing his success in the field, 1984{{cite journal|last=Noel|first=Pamela|title=TV ad wars' newest weapon|journal=Ebony|date=July 1984|oclc=38949612}} }} Anthony Tortorici, director of public relations at Coca-Cola, told ''[[Black Enterprise]]'' magazine in 1981 that the "three most believable personalities are God, [[Walter Cronkite]], and Bill Cosby." At the peak of his advertising career in the mid-1980s, Cosby had a [[Q Score]] of 70, meaning that 70 percent of those responding to a survey of 1,000 United States residents thought highly of him, thus deeming him the most familiar and persuasive endorser.{{cite news|last1=Bialik|first1=Carl|title=Bill Cosby's Fall From Among The Most-Trusted Celebrities To The Least|url=http://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/bill-cosby-rape-allegations-most-trusted-celebrities/|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=FiveThirtyEight|date=5 December 2014}}Pendergrast, p. 362{{refn|Cosby's score of 70 remains unmatched. As of 2014, actor [[Tom Hanks]] was the Q Score leader, with a score of 39.|group=note}} In 2003, industry publication ''[[Advertising Age]]'' said that "during [Cosby's] 14-year reign over the ad industry's public approval index [he had only been surpassed by] [[Pope John Paul II|the Pope]].{{cite news|title=Presenters|url=http://adage.com/article/adage-encyclopedia/presenters/98962/|accessdate=30 January 2013|newspaper=Ad Age Encyclopedia|date=15 September 2003|location=New York NY}} In 2012, the separate Celebrity DBI index listed Cosby as second most-trusted celebrity on a list of celebrities people pay attention to on television, behind [[Morgan Freeman]].{{cite news|last1=Hall|first1=Cheryl|title=Gold medals are fleeting currency in the marketing world|url=http://www.themarketingarm.com/olympic-marketing-endorsements.html|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=The Marketing Arm|agency=Dallas Morning News|date=19 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218114953/http://www.themarketingarm.com/olympic-marketing-endorsements.html|archivedate=18 December 2014|df=}} Professionally, Coca-Cola advertising director John Bergin considered Cosby the company's "greatest weapon"; he said, "magic happens when the camera starts." His enthusiasm was tempered on a personal level, finding him "inconceivably arrogant" and mentioned "blow-ups" on the set.Pendergrast, p. 147 One biographer of Cosby, Linda Etkin, said, "Cosby comes across as a father figure, a teacher, and a friend" in his advertisements.{{cite book|last=Etkin|first=Linda|title=Bill Cosby|year=1985|publisher=Modern Publications|isbn=0-87449-030-8|page=64}} William Turner, in 1982 the marketing manager for Texas Instruments' consumer products group, said Cosby "represents comfort, and people trust him".{{cite journal|last=Wise|first=Deborah|title=Micro makers hike advertising budgets to woo more customers|journal=InfoWorld|date=8 February 1982|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eD4EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA18&dq=texas%20instruments%20bill%20cosby&pg=PA18#v=onepage&q=texas%20instruments%20bill%20cosby&f=false|accessdate=29 July 2011|publisher=Popular Computing, Inc.|location=Palo Alto CA}} In 2014, one educator asked for comment said he remembered Cosby as a "black male authority figure, one of those people who folks that don't live on the edges of the country think of as a good black guy; they trust that guy".{{cite news|last1=Zernike|first1=Kate|title=For Some Fans, Accusations of Rape Crumble Bill Cosby's Wholesome Image|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/23/arts/bill-cosby.html|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=New York Times|date=22 November 2014}} In 1988, a representative for Kodak said Cosby had become "synonymous with quality products and quality services".{{cite journal|title = How Black Stars Help Sell Products On TV|journal = Jet|date = 8 February 1988|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=cLsDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA60&dq=texas+instruments+bill+cosby&hl=en&ei=ZNUyTsreHo-5twekzLn4DA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=texas%20instruments%20bill%20cosby&f=false|accessdate = 25 January 2013|oclc = 60630647}} ''Ebony'' agreed, saying Cosby has the advantage of being able to be selective. Cosby said his belief in their product is an attribute, stating, "if I presented a Bill Cosby who didn't care, their sales would stop right there on the screen. Obviously, I could never do that. Once I believe in the product I aim to sell it, and that's what I think I do better than anybody". An article in ''Black Enterprise'' said part of Cosby's mystique is "that he can endorse a number of products and still retain credibility in each individual sell". Shortly after being signed by Coca-Cola, Cosby appeared at a bottlers' convention. He refused to drink the bottle of Coke he carried on stage, saying, "I'm waiting for all the Jell-O pudding I ate to settle". Cosby said that in childhood, he experienced "periods of addiction" to Coca Cola, consuming fifteen bottles by 2 pm. ==Career in advertising== ===1960s=== [[File:Nat King Cole and Oscar Moore, New York, N.Y., ca. July 1946 (William P. Gottlieb 01541).jpg|right|thumb|Nat King Cole plays a piano, 1946, a photo pre-dating his television series.]] The American advertising industry was initially reluctant to use black spokespeople for fear of angering white customers. ''The [[Nat King Cole]] Show'' (1956-1957), the first nationally syndicated U.S. television series to be hosted by an African American, never found a national sponsor; after its cancellation Cole said, "Madison Avenue is afraid of the dark".{{cite journal|last=Miley|first=Marissa|title=Black Agency Employees Paid 20% Less Than Whites|journal=Advertising Age|date=8 January 2009|url=http://adage.com/article/news/study-ad-agencies-exhibit-pervasive-racial-discrimination/133638/|accessdate=25 January 2013|oclc=39911225|quote=Referencing Nat King Cole's comment that Madison Avenue is afraid of the dark, Mr. Mehri said, "They're going to be afraid of the sunshine we're going to bring to the industry."}}{{cite book|last=Henry|first=Mike|title=Black History: More Than Just a Month|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|location=Plymouth UK|isbn=9781475802610|page=81|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LPgNRyfXF4gC&pg=PA81&dq=%22Madison+Avenue+is+afraid+of+the+dark.%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=GC-xUZvOIOjhyQHXsYCADA&ved=0CDMQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=%22Madison%20Avenue%20is%20afraid%20of%20the%20dark.%22&f=false|date=27 December 2012}}; {{cite book|last=Giddins|first=Gary|title=Visions of Jazz:The First Century|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199879533|page=405|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JtEKSpyt2SUC&pg=PA405&dq=%22Madison+Avenue+is+afraid+of+the+dark.%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=9C6xUf_pNqL4yQHYmIDIDQ&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22Madison%20Avenue%20is%20afraid%20of%20the%20dark.%22&f=false|date=22 October 1998}}; the books say Revlon was the specific instigator of the remark.{{cite book|last=Henderson|first=Amy|title=On the air: pioneers of American broadcasting|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press for the National Portrait Gallery|isbn=9780874744996|page=140|editor=Smithsonian Institution Press for the National Portrait Gallery and Museum of Broadcasting|date=1 October 1988}} Cosby's first advertisement was for [[White Owl]] cigars. His agent approached them in 1965, before the debut of ''[[I Spy (1965 TV series)|I Spy]]'', but after several appearances on the late-night talk program ''[[The Tonight Show]]'', a signifier of success in American comedy. He told agent Norman Brokaw of [[William Morris Agency]] that he liked their tagline, "We're going to get you."{{cite book |last1=Whitaker |first1=Mark |title=Cosby: His Life and Times |date=September 16, 2014 |publisher=Simon and Schuster |isbn=1451697996 |page=269}} Cosby later said there were no commercials "with a black person holding something, buying a product, so the absence of pictures, in retrospect, said a lot". Despite the stigma among advertisers around using a black spokesperson, sales of the product rose.{{cite news|last=Crain|first=Rance|title=Bill Cosby Looks Back on His Life in Commercials|url=http://adage.com/article/news/bill-cosby-back-life-commercials/149599/|accessdate=12 August 2011|newspaper=Ad Age|date=28 March 2011|location=New York NY}} According to an entry in ''Ad Age Encyclopedia'', the public acceptance of Cosby and [[Robert Culp]] appearing as equals on ''I Spy'' made it possible for advertisers to show black people and white people together in their commercials.{{cite news|title=Archetype/Stereotype|url=http://adage.com/article/adage-encyclopedia/archetype-stereotype/98323/|accessdate=30 January 2013|newspaper=Ad Age Encyclopedia|date=15 September 2003|location=New York NY}} ''The Bill Cosby Radio Program'', which debuted in 1968, was sponsored by [[The Coca-Cola Company]]. The series was syndicated to over 200 radio stations by [[McCann Erickson]], Coca-Cola's advertising agency.{{cite web|last=Withers|first=L. M.|title=Coca Cola Presents The Bill Cosby Radio Program|url=http://leemichaelwithers.tripod.com/cosby.htm|work=Coca Cola Presents The Bill Cosby Radio Program|accessdate=26 January 2013|year=2002}} ===1970s=== In 1974, Cosby began promoting [[Jell-O]] pudding for [[General Foods]].{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Andrew F.|title=The Oxford Companion to American Food and Drink|year=2007|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York NY|isbn=0-19-988576-1}} Cosby said comedian [[Jack Benny]], whose program the brand sponsored, was the only previous spokesman for Jell-O,{{cite web|title=Cosby Part 5|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5kUmDYdiYj4|work=Doug Miles and Don Henderson's radio show|publisher=WSLR Radio Sarasota|accessdate=3 December 2011}} but [[Kate Smith]], [[Lucille Ball]], and [[Andy Griffith]] have also pitched the brand.{{cite book|last=Hughes|first=Holly|title=Frommer's 500 Places for Food and Wine Lovers|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=0-470-48064-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gUGOKH5cHnwC&pg=PA58&dq=jello+bill+cosby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HEgEUda6IOT82gWbk4CgBQ&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=jello%20bill%20cosby&f=false|page=58|date=8 April 2009}} In previous campaigns since the brand's launch in 1902, it was targeted towards parents rather than to children, a practice from which the company departed in 2001.{{cite news|last=Thompson|first=Stephanie|title=Jell-O sales jiggle downward; X-treme products readied|url=http://adage.com/article/news/jell-o-sales-jiggle-downward-x-treme-products-readied/33243/|accessdate=30 January 2013|newspaper=Advertising Age|date=19 November 2001|location=New York NY}} Cosby's early commercials were unscripted, but later were written by comedy writers. Cosby disagreed with the writers, who wanted to say the food was for when you were "hungry"; Cosby thought there was not enough substance to satisfy hunger and wanted to use the word "appetite". In 1979, General Foods introduced [[Pudding Pop]]s, the company's first frozen dessert product. With Cosby as spokesperson, it sold US$100 million its first year. After introducing Gelatin Pops and frozen Fruit Bars, the company's frozen desserts sales reached $300 million.{{cite book|last=McMath|first=Robert|title=What Were They Thinking?: Marketing Lessons You Can Learn from Products That Flopped|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|isbn=0-307-79364-8|page=256|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6PfR0mu3ZSgC&pg=PT28&dq=jello+bill+cosby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eE0EUa-KLKO92gWZ34DQBg&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAjgK|date=27 April 2011}} Cosby was engaged to promote the flagging Jell-O gelatin product line in the mid-1980s, when General Foods introduced a holdable Jell-O product called "Jigglers".{{cite news|last=Spackman|first=Christy|title=Mormonism's Jell-O Mold|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/life/food/2012/08/jell_o_and_mormonism_the_stereotype_s_surprising_origins_.html|accessdate=26 January 2013|newspaper=Slate.com|date=17 August 2012|location=Washington DC}} Sales increased seven percent during the first year of the promotion. {{Quote box |width = 30em |border = 1px |align = left |bgcolor = #c6dbf7 |fontsize = 85% |title_bg = |title_fnt = |title = |quoted=yes |quote = My approach from the beginning has been, I want to make the program interrupt the commercial. |salign = right |source = Cosby to ''Ad Age'', 1978. }} Cosby appeared in commercials for Coca-Cola's 1979 campaign, "Have a Coke and a Smile," and made a guest appearance at the Great Get-Together, a major bottlers' convention held that year.Pendergrast, p. 324 This campaign continued into 1981.{{refn|Coca-Cola Canada commissioned a spot titled "Coke is winning", based on A. C. Neilsen Co. of Canada statistics on purchasing trends. The April 1981 ad was pulled a month later, as it violated contracts that neither company could release their figures or mention Neilsen in their ads. Bill Cosby spots were substituted, Coca-Cola claiming this to be the second phase of their campaign, while Pepsi claimed this was a retreat.{{cite news|last1=Westell|first1=Dan|title=Coca-Cola withdraws 'winning' ad|work=The Globe and Mail|date=7 May 1981}}|group=note}} His work in this decade was well received. ''Advertising Age'' named Cosby the top advertising personality of 1978. In 1999, ''[[Advertising Age]]'' magazine named Cosby's 1975 Jell-O commercials, which they called "Bill Cosby with kids", the 92nd best advertising campaign of all time.{{cite news|title=Ad Age Advertising Century: Top 100 Campaigns|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-the-advertising-century/ad-age-advertising-century-top-100-advertising-campaigns/140150/|newspaper=Ad Age|date=29 March 1999}}{{cite news|title=Ad Veteran Curvin O'Rielly Passes Away at 70|last=Messner|first=Tom|url=http://adage.com/article/agency-news/ad-veteran-curvin-o-rielly-passes-70/236562/|accessdate=30 January 2013|newspaper=Advertising Age|date=7 August 2012|location=New York NY}}{{refn|The campaign was introduced by Curvin O'Reilly at Y&R; after launching such a successful campaign featuring Cosby, O'Reilly was later in charge of replacing Cosby at Coca-Cola with [[Max Headroom (character)|Max Headroom]], after the unsuccessful launch of New Coke; see Messner, 2012.|group=note}} ===1980s=== ''Black Enterprise'' magazine found that Cosby was one of only a very few African Americans who could command among the highest fees paid for advertising spokespeople. The 1981 feature also highlighted how rare it was for African Americans to be hired for a complete campaign, as opposed to a single advertisement, despite an overall increase in opportunities. Cosby's agents told the magazine he had earned at least $3 million in current advertising contracts{{spaced ndash}}about one-fifth of his income{{spaced ndash}}the rest of which he earned from live performances.{{cite journal|last=Gayle|first=Stephen|title=Commercial Success|journal=Black Enterprise|date=December 1981|volume=12|issue=5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3ajSred3U2UC&pg=PA53#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=30 April 2012}} Cosby returned as Coca-Cola's spokesperson in its 1982 "Coke Is It" campaign, a series of commercials mocking the [[Pepsi Challenge]]. One advertisement in this series showed a [[Pepsi]] [[vending machine]] to mock the brand, which author [[Mark Pendergrast]] called "unthinkable". Another said Pepsi Challenge commercials were misleading because they never showed anyone choosing Coke. John Bergin, who directed the series of commercials, personally disliked Cosby but said his presence in Coca-Cola advertising ended the first Pepsi Challenge campaign in 1983.Pendergrast, p. 346 {{Quote box |width = 30em |border = 1px |align = left |bgcolor = #c6dbf7 |fontsize = 85% |title_bg = |title_fnt = |title = |quoted=yes |quote = Now see, if you were another cola, number 2 or number 29, you'd do taste tests and challenges and stuff and try to compare yourself to this, wouldn't you? Sure, don't shake your head, you would too, you sneaky devil. |salign = right |source = Cosby in a Coca-Cola ad, c. 1982. }} In mid-1982, Cosby was hired by [[Texas Instruments]] to appear in television advertisements for the company's [[Texas Instruments TI-99/4A|TI-99/4A]] home computer. He was to be paid $1 million a year for the campaign.{{cite book|title=Pennsylvania biographical dictionary|year=1988|publisher=North American Book Dist LLC |isbn=0-403-09950-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iD4EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PT32&dq=texas%20instruments%20bill%20cosby&pg=PT32#v=onepage&q=texas%20instruments%20bill%20cosby&f=false|edition=2}} {{cite journal|last=Nocera|first=Joseph|title=Death of a computer|journal=Texas Monthly|date=April 1984|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DSsEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA230&dq=texas%20instruments%20bill%20cosby&pg=PA225#v=onepage&q=bill%20cosby&f=false|accessdate=29 July 2011}} Pages 225 and 230. The company touted Cosby's education and rapport with adults and children.{{cite journal|last=Chin|first=Kathy|title=Computer companies hitch stars to high-tech wagon|journal=InfoWorld|date=4 July 1983|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xy8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA14&dq=bill+cosby+spokesman&hl=en&ei=T4LaTrGNBOTl0QHRzeH2DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=bill%20cosby%20spokesman&f=false|accessdate=3 December 2011}} The campaign was aimed at parents, rather than children, as was the campaign for the [[Commodore 64]]. Cosby was the face of a mystery rebate program, offering reimbursements of between $3 and $1,000.{{cite journal|title=Texas Instruments' 'Mystery Rebate'|journal=InfoWorld|date=16 March 1981|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iD4EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PT32&dq=texas%20instruments%20bill%20cosby&pg=PT32#v=onepage&q=texas%20instruments%20bill%20cosby&f=false|accessdate=29 July 2011|publisher=Popular Computing, Inc.|location=Palo Alto CA}} [[J. Fred Bucy]], who was head of Texas Instruments' home computer operation in 1983, scrapped Cosby's advertisements to focus on the product's educational value. [[Radio Shack]] vice-president of marketing David Beckerman said, "A celebrity draws attention to the product. Even if we had President Reagan on our ads, we wouldn't sell any more computers. A product sells itself. A celebrity causes indirect sales." Cosby, along with entrepreneur [[James Bruce Llewellyn]], bought stock in a Philadelphia Coca-Cola bottler in 1983 as part of the company's push to increase African American participation in the company. This was, in part, a response to pressure by [[Jesse Jackson]]'s [[Rainbow/PUSH|PUSH]] campaign.{{cite journal|title=Cosby Buys Coke Stock|journal=Black Enterprise|date=December 1983|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G-qnNFgxZYMC&lpg=PA28&dq=bill%20cosby%20ad&pg=PA28#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=28 July 2011}}{{cite news|last=Greising|first=David|title=I'd Like the World to Buy a Coke: The Life and Leadership of Roberto Goizueta|page=93}}{{refn|After purchasing some of the Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of New York Inc. in 1984, [[Julius Erving]] was announced as a new spokesperson for the brand.{{cite news|last1=Oliver|first1=Thomas|title=Dr. J scores twice with Coca-Cola|work=The Globe and Mail|agency=Cox News Service|date=9 February 1984}}|group=note}} [[File:New Coke can.jpg|upright|thumb|right|Spots with Cosby calling Pepsi too sweet were ill-advised, given the introduction of the reformulated sweeter tasting "[[New Coke]]".]] At the height of the [[Cola Wars]], marketer [[Sergio Zyman]] persuaded Coca-Cola executives to create and air commercials with Cosby praising Coke for being less sweet than Pepsi,{{cite book|last=Oliver|title=The Real Coke, The Real Story|pages=114–115}} which was aired only in areas where sales of Pepsi were dominant. One commercial from the series features Cosby "rubberfacing an icky frown" and describing Pepsi as "gooey".{{cite news|last=Greising|first=David|title=I'd Like the World to Buy a Coke: The Life and Leadership of Roberto Goizueta|page=122}} These advertisements were broadcast from October 1984; Coca-Cola's independently owned bottlers demanded the commercials were run in their markets as well. Zyman said despite the upcoming contradiction, the ads were the first boost to Coke's image in years. Coca-Cola was simultaneously testing possible new variations of its soft drink and decided it would sell more product if it used a sweeter formula. Once [[New Coke]] was launched, Pepsi prepared its public response to the change; among its talking points for journalists writing about New Coke was to "Ask them about those Bill Cosby ads".Oliver, page 129. One of a new series of Coke advertisements showed Cosby dressed in a [[toga]]; this campaign was described as unconvincing.{{cite news|last=Greising|first=David|title=I'd Like the World to Buy a Coke: The Life and Leadership of Roberto Goizueta|page=124}} Coca-Cola faced a widespread public backlash, internal dissent, and ultimately the original drink recipe returned as "Coca-Cola Classic".Pendergrast, pp. 354–371{{cite web | url=http://www.coca-colacompany.com/stories/coke-lore-new-coke | title=The Real Story of New Coke | publisher=The Coca-Cola Company | work=Coke Lore | accessdate=October 10, 2011}} In the days following the reversal, an editorial cartoon featured Cosby pouring a can of Pepsi into a can of Coke.Oliver, page 143. [[Marcio Moreira]], a McCann Erickson creative executive behind the New Coke introduction, said in 2011 that the decision to hire Cosby was not made until other commercials were being edited.{{cite news|last=Moreira|first=Marcio|title=How New Coke Went From Market-Changer to Company's Humbling Biggest Blunder|url=http://adage.com/article/guest-columnists/coke-company-s-humbling-biggest-blunder/227293/|accessdate=30 January 2013|newspaper=Advertising Age|date=2 May 2011|location=New York NY}} ''[[The Cosby Show]]'' debuted in 1984, becoming "TV's biggest hit in the 1980s" and reviving both the sitcom genre and NBC.{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/cosby/cast/100456 |title=Cosby Show: TV Guide News |accessdate=2007-09-23 |work=TVGuide.com}} Before the series premiere, Cosby told reporters his income from commercials for Coke and Ford, as well as his [[Las Vegas]] shows, had made him financially secure.{{cite news|last=Vick|first=Karl|title=Tough ad pitch: When Cosby talks, America listens|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=o3dIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=f2ADAAAAIBAJ&dq=bill%20cosby%20del-monte&pg=4625%2C4505699|accessdate=26 July 2011|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=5 August 1986|location=St. Petersburg FL}} At some point before 1985, Cosby featured in advertisements for [[Bird's Eye]] frozen foods.{{cite news|last=Mehren|first=Elizabeth|title=Cosby agrees to write book on fatherhood|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NiAyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=16UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1088,168830&dq=bird's+eye+bill+cosby&hl=en|accessdate=5 January 2013|newspaper=Montreal Gazette|date=1 August 1985|location=Montreal QC}} In 1986, Cosby's only contract was with Jell-O, but by the end of the year he had added two more endorsements.{{cite news|last=Dougherty|first=Philip H.|title=ADVERTISING; Bill Cosby to Appear For Kodak Colorwatch|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/12/24/business/advertising-bill-cosby-to-appear-for-kodak-colorwatch.html|accessdate=26 January 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=24 December 1986|location=New York NY}} By August, Cosby began promoting [[E. F. Hutton & Co.]] with a series of print and television advertisements, and comedy concerts.{{cite news|last=Wollenberg|first=Skip|title=Hutton picks Cosby as spokesperson|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=S5Q_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=8FUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2376,4638899&dq=hutton+bill+cosby&hl=en|accessdate=5 January 2013|newspaper=The Vindicator|date=27 April 1986|location=Youngstown OH|oclc=53295875}} The company had been accused of fraud and needed a spokesperson who was well-liked.{{cite news |first=Nathaniel C. |last=Nash |title=E.F. Hutton guilty in bank fraud: penalties could top $10 million |url=|work=The New York Times |publisher=|date=1985-05-03|oclc=27999397}}{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Halloran |title=U.S. Hints at Hutton Indictment in Money Scheme |url=|work=New York Times |publisher=|date=2007-10-11 |oclc=27999397}} Soon after Cosby's commercials aired, the company merged with [[Morgan Stanley Smith Barney]].{{cite news |first=James|last=Sterngold|title=How They Tore Hutton to Pieces |work=New York Times |publisher=|date=1988-01-17 }} In late December, he added [[J. Walter Thompson]] agency account [[Kodak Colorwatch System]] photographic processing system to his list. The estimated $10 million contract included commercials featuring Cosby to run in print, on television, as [[point of sale]], and in promotional programs.{{cite book|last=Ruuth|first=Marianne|title=Bill Cosby: Entertainer|year=1992|publisher=Los Angeles, California: Melrose Square|isbn=0-87067-596-6|page=98}} Coca-Cola purchased [[Columbia Pictures]] in 1982.Pendergrast, p. 374Pendergrast, p. 386 In 1987, Columbia decided revenues from its spy comedy ''[[Leonard Part 6]]'' (1987) would offset its losses on ''[[Ishtar (film)|Ishtar]]'' (1987). Leading up to release, Columbia announced it would spend $12 million on "synergies" with the film, taking into account the success of Cosby's television series and record sales for his parenting book, [[Fatherhood (book)|''Fatherhood'']]. Promotions included posters, spy cameras, point of sale [[standees]] of Cosby, and a contest to win [[Porsche]] cars.Pendergrast, p. 387{{cite journal|title=Selling Soft Drinks & Celluloid|journal=Journey|date=November 1987|pages=4–8}}, as referenced in Pendergrast on page 386, citation on page 516. Cosby, who acted in and produced the film, was initially supportive of it, but close to the release date he publicly distanced himself from it.{{cite news|title=Cosby hates 'Leonard'|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0ONWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=R0INAAAAIBAJ&pg=1079,6764542&dq=cosby+coca-cola&hl=en|accessdate=26 January 2013|newspaper=The Miami News|date=24 December 1987|location=Miami FL|page=2A}} The film failed, with a net loss of $33 million. In the 1980s, Cosby also appeared in [[public service announcements]]. To increase black participation in the [[1990 United States Census]], the bureau recruited Cosby, [[Magic Johnson]], [[Alfre Woodard]], and Miss America [[Debbye Turner]] as spokespeople.{{cite journal|last = Brown|first = Frank Dexter|title = The 1990 Census: Will Blacks Be Counted Out?|journal = Black Enterprise|date=February 1990|volume = 20|issue = 7|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=hl4EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA196&dq=bill%20cosby%20ad&pg=PA196#v=onepage&q=bill%20cosby&f=false|accessdate = 29 July 2011|page = 195|publisher = Earl G. Graves, Ltd.|issn = 0006-4165}} ===1990s to 2010s=== [[File:Bill Cosby (left) production assistant (center) Ginna Marston (right).jpg|right|thumb|Cosby prepares to film a public service announcement for [[Partnership for Drug-Free Kids|Partnership for a Drug-Free America]]. He is seen with a production assistant and [[Ginna Marston]], an advertising executive who produced the spot ''[[This Is Your Brain on Drugs]]''. Cosby also created a 1971 album titled ''[[Bill Cosby Talks to Kids About Drugs]]''.]] Cosby continued to be a Jell-O spokesman through the 1990s. He was present for the lighting of the brand's first billboard in New York's [[Times Square]] in 1998.{{cite news|title=Jell-O in Big Apple:|url=http://adage.com/article/news/jell-o-big-apple/65650/|accessdate=30 January 2013|newspaper=Advertising Age|date=1 June 1998|location=New York NY}} In 1999, Cosby's 25th year as spokesman for Jell-O, was also the final year he appeared in its advertising. The company distributed 120,000 copies of his picture book series, ''[[Little Bill (book series)|Little Bill]]'', into American public libraries.{{cite news|title=Cosby, Jello mark 25th anniversary|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sWowAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LTUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4814,9410687&dq=little+bill+jello&hl=en|accessdate=3 December 2011|newspaper=Rome News-Tribune|date=30 April 1999|location=Rome, Georgia}} Despite the transitions of advertising agencies{{refn|[[Young & Rubicam Advertising]] had the Jell-O account since 1926, but lost it to [[Draftfcb|FCB]] in 2000.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/08/business/media-business-advertising-giants-engage-battle-for-billings-daimlerchrysler.html?pagewanted=2|last=Elliott|first=Stuart|title=Giants Engage in Battle for Billings as DaimlerChrysler Conducts Assignment Review|newspaper=New York Times|date=8 September 2000|accessdate=26 May 2015}}|group=note}} and the 1989 merger of General Foods into [[Kraft]], Cosby remained with Jell-O.{{cite news|title=Kraft Foods|url=http://adage.com/article/adage-encyclopedia/kraft-foods/98739/|accessdate=30 January 2013|newspaper=Advertising Age|date=15 September 2003|location=New York NY}} He appeared at the [[Utah State Senate]] in 2001 to designate Jell-O [[List of Utah state symbols|the official state snack]],{{cite news|last=Swinyard|first=Kersten|title=Jell-O jiggles its way through Senate vote|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/822795/Jell-O-jiggles-its-way-through-Senate-vote.html|accessdate=26 January 2013|newspaper=Deseret News|date=1 February 2001|location=Deseret UT}}{{cite book|last=Griggs|first=Brandon|title=Utah Curiosities: Quirky Characters, Roadside Oddities & Other Offbeat Stuff|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=978-0-7627-4386-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bXi0RNY7MmIC&pg=PA68&dq=jello+bill+cosby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eE0EUa-KLKO92gWZ34DQBg&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=jello%20bill%20cosby&f=false|page=68|chapter=Hello, Jell-o!|date=1 October 2007}} and made a promotional visit to the [[Jell-O Gallery]] in 2004. In 2010, Cosby returned to Jell-O as executive producer for the company's "Hello Jell-O" campaign. In return, the brand sponsored his weekly web show ''[[OBKB]]'', a children's interview series similar to ''[[Kids Say the Darndest Things]]''.{{cite web|last=Fredrix|first=Emily|title=Bill Cosby & Jell-O: Together Again|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/05/17/bill-cosby-jell-o-togethe_n_578592.html|work=The Huffington Post|publisher=TheHuffingtonPost.com|accessdate=3 December 2011|date=16 May 2010}} As of 2002, Cosby's time with Jell-O was considered the longest-standing celebrity endorsement in American advertising history.{{cite book|last=Cross|first=Mary|title=A century of American icons: 100 products and slogans from the 20th century consumer culture|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=978-0-313-31481-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ecgiAQAAIAAJ&q=jello+bill+cosby&dq=jello+bill+cosby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=DXgIUer0F8u_0QH8m4CYAQ&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAjge|date=30 September 2002}} In the 1990s, Bill Cosby was also the spokesperson for Service Merchandise. {{cite news|title=Service Merchandise commercial|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vM-FiwgiWcU}} At the [[Advertising Hall of Fame]] induction ceremonies on March 30, 2011, Cosby was the first winner of the American Advertising Federation's President's Award for Contributions to Advertising, for special achievements in the field. ==Criticism== In 1973, ''[[The Village Voice]]'' writer Terry Guerin said Cosby was past his prime. Among the reasons, "making spokesman commercials for such established heels as White Owl cigars and Pan American airlines. He has evolved into a kind of self-parodying sap, the kind of flagrant, perpetual parader [[Sammy Davis, Jr.|Sammy Davis]] has always been".{{cite news|last=Guerin|first=Terry|title=Transfiguration of Frazier & Co.|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=k9RHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_YsDAAAAIBAJ&dq=bill%20cosby%20white-owl&pg=6443%2C2785538 |accessdate=26 July 2011|newspaper=The Village Voice|date=10 May 1973|location=New York NY|page=39}} "The Noble Cos," a 1986 satirical editorial by [[Edward Sorel]] for ''[[The Nation]]'', was written in Cosby's imagined voice. It echoed the comments of other authors that Cosby had become out-of-touch with lower-class African Americans.{{cite book|last=Dyson|first=Michael Eric|title=Is Bill Cosby Right?: Or Has the Black Middle Class Lost Its Mind?|year=2006|publisher=Basic Civitas Books|isbn=0-465-01720-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rs5mrCyaaTEC|pages=83–84}} In response to this sentiment, Cosby said in 1997, "So this buddy says, 'I didn't mind your commercials for Jello, Del Monte, Ford cars ... Ideal Toys, or Coca-Cola, although Coke does do business in South Africa ... But, Bill, why do commercials for those crooks at E. F. Hutton?' My buddy didn't understand my commercials improve race relations. Y'see, by showing that a black man can be just as money-hungry as a white man ... I'm proving that all men are brothers."{{cite book|last = Dyson|first = Michael Eric|title = Is Bill Cosby Right?: Or Has the Black Middle Class Lost Its Mind?|year = 2006|publisher = Basic Books|isbn = 978-0-465-01720-1|page = 288|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rs5mrCyaaTEC&pg=PA84&dq=But,+Bill,+why+do+commercials+for+those+crooks+at+E.+F.+Hutton&hl=en&sa=X&ei=207_ULDUK8mw2QXs8IHwBg&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=But%2C%20Bill%2C%20why%20do%20commercials%20for%20those%20crooks%20at%20E.%20F.%20Hutton}}; quote believed to have originated in "[http://business.highbeam.com/435553/article-1G1-56526077/sharing-humor-sharing-tears Sharing Humor, Sharing Tears]", ''St Louis Post-Dispatch'', 20 January 1997. In 1981, Cosby told ''[[Black Enterprise]]'' magazine: {{quote|In this business, many of us are well paid but we are not all that wealthy. You may read 'X-number of dollar goes to so and so,' but remember, everybody takes a cut – the lawyer, the agent, the publicist. If a company comes along and says 'We'd like you to talk about how much you enjoy wearing this warm-up suit,' and the money is right, I'm going to do it. Jell-O was a dessert in my house when I was a kid. My mom served Del Monte fruit cocktail when I was growing up. They want to pay me to say I eat these products, well, I eat them. I came out of a lower economic area, and this is money. This is a business ... show business. A great deal of our careers depends on keeping ourselves in the public eye. I think performers should take advantage of commercial offers if they're satisfied with the product.}} ===Sexual assault and rape allegations=== {{main|Bill Cosby sexual assault case}} In October 2014, a stand-up comedy routine by [[Hannibal Buress]], addressing allegations of rape against Cosby, went viral on [[YouTube]].{{cite news|last1=O'Keefe|first1=Megan|title=Comic Hannibal Buress calls Cosby a "rapist"|url=http://decider.com/2014/10/21/hannibal-buress-calls-bill-cosby-a-rapist/?_ga=1.220824862.726639338.1417731143|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=Decider|date=21 October 2014}} On November 10, Cosby posted a message requesting [[Internet meme|meme]] images, using a hashtag of #CosbyMeme, on his [[Twitter]] feed. Many of the images posted in response related to the allegations, which were fresh in the respondents' minds.{{cite news|last1=Paunescu|first1=Delia|title=Bill Cosby's massive social media fail|url=https://nypost.com/2014/11/10/bill-cosby-twitter-hasthag-meme-immediately-backfired/?_ga=1.246349826.726639338.1417731143|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=NY Post|date=10 November 2014}} After numerous women came forward as victims of Cosby's alleged actions, a television special and a series in development were cancelled.{{cite news|last1=Sinha-Roy|first1=Piya|title=NBC, Netflix cancel Bill Cosby's shows after sex assault claims|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/19/us-people-billcosby-idUSKCN0J30CO20141119|accessdate=7 December 2014|agency=Reuters|date=19 November 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Oldham|first1=Stuart|title=Netflix Pulls Bill Cosby Special Amid Rape Allegations|url=https://variety.com/2014/biz/news/netflix-pulls-bill-cosby-special-amid-rape-allegations-1201359886/|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=Variety|date=18 November 2014}}{{cite news|author1=Bill Carter|author2=Graham Bowley|author3=Lorne Manly|title=Comeback by Bill Cosby Unravels as Rape Claims Re-emerge|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/20/business/media/bill-cosby-fallout-rape-accusations.html?_r=0|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=New York Times|date=19 November 2014}} Cosby refused to address the situation; his lawyer said such actions would dignify "decade-old, discredited" allegations.{{cite news|last1=Moyer|first1=Justin|title=Bill Cosby's silence further explained by NPR's Scott Simon|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/11/17/nprs-scott-simon-further-explains-bill-cosbys-silence-in-detailed-tweets-cnn-appearance/|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=Washington Post|date=17 November 2014}}{{cite news|title=Bill Cosby maintains silence, but can he outlast accusations of sexual assault?|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2014/11/18/bill-cosby-maintains-silence-accusations-sexual-assault/|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=FOX News|agency=Associated Press|date=18 November 2014}} Many media outlets commented on the way such actions clashed with his image as "America's Dad".{{cite news|last1=Prince|first1=Rosa|title=Bill Cosby's reputation in tatters as rape allegations return to haunt 'America's Dad'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/11234223/Bill-Cosbys-reputation-in-tatters-as-rape-allegations-return-to-haunt-Americas-Dad.html|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=The Telegraph|date=16 November 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Edelman|first1=Joni|title=Bill Cosby Was A Father Figure—How Do I Reconcile This With The Rape Allegations?|url=http://www.ravishly.com/2014/12/03/bill-cosby-rape-molestation-allegations-lawsuit-personal-essay|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=Ravishly|date=3 December 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Osterheldt|first1=Jeneé|title=Bill Cosby is no Cliff Huxtable|url=http://www.kansascity.com/living/liv-columns-blogs/jenee-osterheldt/article3985398.html|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=The Kansas City Star|date=17 November 2014}} One of the accusers felt nobody would believe her claims at the time of the alleged incident, given Cosby's status in advertising. Joan Tarshis told the media that Cosby was "Mr America; Mr Jello, as I called him".{{cite news|last1=Molloy|first1=Antonia|title=Bill Cosby: CNN anchor Don Lemon tells accuser who claims they were raped by comedian 'There are ways not to perform oral sex'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/bill-cosby-there-are-ways-not-to-perform-oral-sex-cnn-anchor-don-lemon-tells-accuser-9869633.html|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=The Independent|date=19 November 2014}} The publicity surrounding the allegations had a drastic effect on Cosby's reputation, as seen in the following drop in his ratings. In March 2013, Cosby had a 76.3 rating on the [[Davie-Brown Index]], a rating of the public perceptions of roughly 3500 personalities published by [[Omnicom Group]] company [[The Marketing Arm]], placing him as the third most-trusted celebrity, behind Morgan Freeman and [[Mehmet Oz|Dr. Mehmet Oz]]. By November 19, this had fallen to 57.1, placing him at either the 2,626th spot or 2615th,{{cite news|last1=Vranica|first1=Suzanne|title=Bill Cosby Falls From #3 to #2,615 in List of Most Trusted Celebrities|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/cmo/2014/11/25/bill-cosby-falls-from-3-to-2615-in-list-of-most-trusted-celebrities/|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=Wall Street Journal|date=25 November 2014}} depending on the source. The same company's separate rating on who consumers view as an "effective product spokesperson" saw Cosby drop to 2,746th spot; at one point, he had been 5th. Awareness of Cosby increased from 63rd to 51st. The Marketing Arm warns about misinterpreting the ratings fall; it said 900 celebrities were within the [[margin of error]] for Cosby's rating. At the time of the accusations, [[E-Poll Market Research]] had not updated its scores; a [[Q Score]] for Cosby was not expected until 2015. The executive vice-president of Q Scores Co. said polling in the midst of a scandal would likely overstate the score's longterm effects. All three companies' scores are updated at different intervals, meaning they are not directly comparable. Jell-O was relatively unaffected on social media by allegations against Cosby. The brand was mentioned in one percent of posts about Cosby, which was considered low. Still, negative connections continued, including by rapper [[Eminem]] in a [[freestyle rap]],{{cite web|url=http://www.sohh.com/eminem-proves-hes-still-got-it-blasts-bill-cosby-w-jello-o-freestyle-audio/|website=[[SOHH]]|title=Eminem proves he's still got it, blasts Bill Cosby w/ "Jello-o" Freestyle|date=July 23, 2015|last=Jones|first=Biz}} and an article by ''Food Drink and Franchise'' magazine pointed out moments in commercials that were awkward in retrospect.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fdfworld.com/retailing/392/Six-Bill-Cosby-Jell-O-Commercials-That-Are-Just-Awkward-Now|website=Food Drink Franchise|title=Six Bill Cosby Jell-O Commercials That Are Just Awkward Now|first=Sasha|last=Orman|date=December 3, 2014}} The numerous accusations of [[rape]], [[drug facilitated sexual assault]], [[sexual battery]], [[child sexual abuse]], and [[sexual misconduct]] spanned from 1965 to 2008 across ten [[U.S. state]]s and one [[Canadian province]].{{cite web |url= http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/11/24/bill-cosby-s-long-list-of-accusers-so-far-17-alleged-sexual-assault-victims-between-1965-2004.html| title= Bill Cosby’s Long List of Accusers (So Far): 18 Alleged Sexual Assault Victims Between 1965–2004|work=The Daily Beast| first= Marlow| last= Stern|accessdate=December 6, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Seemayer|first1=Zach|title=Bill Cosby's Accusers: A Timeline of Alleged Sexual Assault Claims (Updated)|url=http://www.etonline.com/news/154160_timeline_of_bill_cosby_sexual_assault_allegations|publisher=ET Online|access-date=April 24, 2015|date=February 26, 2015}}{{cite web|first1=Filipa|last1=Ioannou|first2=Ben|last2=Mathis-Lilley|first3=Elliot|last3=Hannon|title=A Complete List of the Women Who Have Accused Bill Cosby of Sexual Assault|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2014/11/21/bill_cosby_accusers_list_sexual_assault_rape_drugs_feature_in_women_s_stories.html|publisher=Slate|access-date=April 24, 2015|date=November 21, 2014}} On September 25, 2018, Cosby was sentenced to 3 to 10 years in state prison for sexual assault for an assault against Andrea Constand.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-45644374|title=Cosby sentenced to prison for sex assault|last=|first=|date=September 25, 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=September 25, 2018|language=en-GB}} ==Footnotes== {{reflist|group=note}} ==Works cited== * {{cite book|last=Greising|first=David|title=I'd Like the World to Buy a Coke: The Life and Leadership of Roberto Goizueta|year=1998|publisher=Wiley|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-0471345947}} * {{cite book|last=Oliver|first=Thomas|title=The Real Coke, The Real Story|year=1986|publisher=Random House|location=New York, NY|isbn=0-394-55273-3}} * {{cite book|last=Pendergrast|first=Mark|authorlink=Mark Pendergrast|title=For God, Country, and Coca-Cola: The Unauthorized History of the Great American Soft Drink and the Company That Makes It|year=2000|publisher=MacMillan Publishing Company|location=New York, NY|isbn=0-684-19347-7}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Bill Cosby}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cosby, The '''Borzu Nama''' (pronounced as Borzū-Nāma or Borzū-Nāme) ({{lang-fa| برزونامه}}) is a [[Persian language|Persian]] epic poem of about 65,000 couplets recounting the exploits and adventures of the legendary hero Borzu, son of [[Sohrab]]<ref name="IranicaBorzu">William L. Hanaway, "Borzu-Nama" in Encyclopedia Iranica. [http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/borzu-nama-epic-poem-1] accessed October, 2010</ref><ref name="Iranica2">BORZU-NĀMA (article 2) in Encyclopedia Iranica by Gabrielle van den Berg. [http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/borzu-nama-2-epic-poem] accessed October, 2010.</ref> and grandson of [[Rostam]].
==Plot==
[[Abraham Hyacinthe Anquetil-Duperron]] identifies the author as 'Ata'i, who is further identified as 'Amid Abu'l 'Ala' 'Ata b. Yaqub Kateb Razi by Blochet. He was a poet of the [[Ghaznavid]] court and died around 1078-1079. The language of the Borzu-nama is characteristics of texts of the 11th century. The story is versified in the same meter and style of [[Ferdowsi]]'s [[Shahnama]]. The Borzu-nama is possibly the longest of the post [[Shahnama]] epic poems and includes material from [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] national legends not used by [[Ferdowsi]].<ref name="IranicaBorzu"/>
The story starts with [[Sohrab]] the son of [[Rostam]]. On his way from [[Turan]] to fight the Iranians he marries a woman named Shahru. Before leaving, he gives her a token to give to their unborn child. The child is named Borzu by Shahru and she raises him without disclosing his father's identity. The young Borzu is recruited into [[Afrasiab]]'s, the King of Turan, army. Borzu eventually forces his mother to reveal his father's name. On finding that it was [[Sohrab]], he sets off to battle [[Rostam]] to avenge his father's death. [[Afrasiab]] then sends him with an army to [[Iran]], but Borzu is captured by Rostam's son [[Faramarz nama|Faramarz]] and taken to [[Sistan]]. Shahru is informed of Borzu's capture, and helps him escape. He is recaptured by [[Rostam]], and not recognizing his grandfather, Borzu battles [[Rostam]]. His life is spared at the last minute when Shahru reveals their relationship. Borzu and Rostam embrace and Borzu joins the Iranian forces. [[Afrasiab]] learns of this and sends Susan-e Rameshgar, a musician and sorceress to capture Rostam and Borzu. Afrasiab arrives with his army and the epic takes up a long series of battles and adventures that include famous Iranian and Turanian heroes from the Shahnameh, along with [[Daeva|Div]]s, [[Peri|Paris]] (fairies) and wizards. The tale concludes with the death of Borzu at the hands of a [[Daeva|Div]].
== Editions == The Borzu-nama has not yet been published in a critical edition, but versions of the text have been included in the Shah Nama editions of both Turner Macan (pp. 2160–296) and Dabirsiāqi.<ref name="Iranica2"/>
==Possible influences== Friedrich von Suhtschek, in a discussion of the Iranian sources of the Grail legend, claimed, but did not prove, that the Borzu Nama is the direct source of [[Wolfram von Eschenbach]]’s [[Parzifal]].

'''Boudoir photography''' is a photographic style featuring intimate, romantic, and sometimes erotic images of its subjects in a photographic studio, bedroom or private dressing room environment,{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} primarily intended for the private enjoyment of the subject and his or her romantic partners.<ref name="Shelp">{{cite book|last=Shelp|first=Scott G.|title=A Comprehensive Beginner's Guide to Photography, Second Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tQcyAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA116|accessdate=31 December 2015|publisher=Lulu.com|isbn=9780557164493|page=116}}</ref> It is distinct from [[glamour photography|glamour]] and [[Nude photography (art)|art nude]] photography in that it is usually more suggestive rather than explicit in its approach to nudity and sexuality, features subjects who do not regularly [[Model (people)|model]], and produces images that are not intended to be seen by a wide audience, but rather to remain under the control of the subject.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fstoppers.com/business/why-you-may-not-be-boudoir-photographer-even-though-you-think-you-are-77741|title=Why You May Not Be A Boudoir Photographer Even Though You Think You Are |last=Bastita|first=Nino|accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref>
== History ==
Nude or sexualized female forms have been a theme of photography since as early as 1840.<ref name="Warren2005">{{cite book|last=Warren|first=Lynne|title=Encyclopedia of Twentieth-Century Photography, 3-Volume Set|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cFVsBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA448|accessdate=31 December 2015|date=2005-11-15|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135205430|page=448}}</ref> Early [[erotic photography]], such as [[French postcard]]s from the late 19th and early 20th century, [[pin-up girl]]s, and [[Hollywood]] culture have influenced the visual style of boudoir photography.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wgno.com/2014/07/18/a-peek-inside-boudoir-photography/|title=A Peek Inside Boudoir Photography|last=Sinkovits|first=Tanya|date=July 18, 2014|publisher=WGNO|accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref> Notable early boudoir photographers include [[Albert Arthur Allen]], who photographed larger women against ornate backgrounds.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Malouf |first1=Caroline |title=Boudoir Photography |url=https://carolinemalouf.com/boudoir-blog/the-history-of-boudoir-photography |website=Caroline Malouf Photography |accessdate=24 October 2018}}</ref>
Boudoir photography was popularised in the millennium with the arrival of digital photography.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/businessclub/8216254/Tough-lessons-for-entrepreneurs-in-2010.html|title=Miss|last=Alexandra|first=Vince|date=|website=The Telegraph Newspaper|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> It became popular with women seeking to create a private collection of professional studio portraits. Boudoir photography dates from the mid-1980s onwards,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20089896,00.html|title=Now for Some Real Play Mates! Boudoir Photography Proves Wives and Girlfriends Can Be Sexy, Too|last=Calio|first=Jim|date=Feb 11, 1985|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref> and is characterized by the empowerment of its female subjects, who now are typically the photographer's direct clients<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/marisa-leigh/where-did-boudoir-photography-come-from_b_4654991.html|title=Where Did Boudoir Photography Come From?|last=Leigh|first=Marisa|date=3 February 2014|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref> rather than being hired models.
== Appeal ==
It is common for women to have boudoir photographs of themselves made as a gift to a partner, conventionally on the occasion of their engagement, marriage,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.neerajagnihotri.com/boudoir-photography-india/|title=Luxury Boudoir Photography in India - Neeraj Agnihotri|work=NEERAJ AGNIHOTRI|access-date=2018-05-08|language=en-US}}</ref> or before an enforced separation such as a military deployment.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=HCcEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA55&dq=%22boudoir+photographs%22+deployment&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi4oN_6-oTKAhUL2R4KHdd1Dr8Q6AEIIzAB#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Centerfold|last=Surina|first=Echo|year=2009|work=Exquisite Weddings|accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref> In the [[United Kingdom]] it became popular for brides-to-be to commission photoshoots as a wedding gift for the groom.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://startups.co.uk/young-guns/alexandra-burns/|title=Miss|last=Vince|first=Alexandra|date=March 25, 2011|website=Startups|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Boudoir photography is also sometimes given as a gift with the intention of re-affirming and encouraging the romance and sensuality between partners in a long-term relationship.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/sep/02/boudoir-photography-orthodox-jewish-women|title=In the boudoir with Orthodox Jewish women | work=The Guardian|last=Kanim|first=Debra|date=2 Sep 2015|accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref>
Increasingly, boudoir photography is seen as something that a person might do purely for their own enjoyment, for the pleasure and affirmation of seeing themselves as attractive, daring, sensual, and sexually-desirable.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kentucky.com/living/health-and-medicine/article44037471.html|title=Boudoir photos help women reconnect with sexy side|last=Meehan|first=Mary|date=June 22, 2010|work=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]|accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/posed-lingerie-celebrate/story-25965365-detail/story.html|title=I posed in my lingerie to celebrate ME! How sexy Boudouir photo-shoots unlocked the inner confidence of three Devon mums|last=Barnes|first=W M N C|date=4 February 2015|work=Western Morning News|accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref>
== Styles ==
Boudoir photography encompasses a range of styles and moods. Named categories of boudoir photography include so-called "naughty girl", "fun and giggles", and "provocative and sensual", with varying degrees of explicitness and nudity.<ref name="Lynch2013">{{cite book|last=Lynch|first=Annette|title=Porn Chic: Exploring the Contours of Raunch Eroticism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oasYAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT76|accessdate=31 December 2015|date=2013-08-15|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=9781472520142|pages=76–}}</ref>
Visually the genre is characterized by diffuse [[high-key lighting|high-key]] images<ref name="Hewlett2014">{{cite book|last=Hewlett|first=Terry|title=Flash Photography: Art and Techniques|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7zOCBAAAQBAJ&pg=SA5-PA92|accessdate=31 December 2015|date=2014-07-31|publisher=Crowood Press, Limited|isbn=9781847977670|page=5}}</ref> that flatter the appearance of skin, short focal distances, and shallow [[depth of field]],<ref name="Lark2014">{{cite book|last=Lark|first=Jessica|title=Elegant Boudoir Photography: Lighting, Posing, and Design for Exquisite Images|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vb69BQAAQBAJ&pg=PA91|accessdate=31 December 2015|date=2014-05-13|publisher=Amherst Media|isbn=9781608957279|page=91}}</ref> which together impart an intimate, "dreamy" mood. Other common styles include a low-key, deliberately grainy black-and-white, reflecting the influence of art nudes, early erotic photography, and [[film noir]].<ref name="Lark2014" /> Also common are poses and lighting setups intended to replicate the mood and appearance of classic pin-up photographs and paintings.<ref>{{cite book|title=25 Amazing Boudoir Photography Techniques|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qymxcIKXCuIC&pg=PA44|publisher=Edward Verosky|page=44}}</ref>

{{more references|date=December 2016}} '''Czech Games Edition''' is a company created in 2007 in [[Czech Republic]] that produces board and card games.
