Music Video * Notes: The set was released as a celebration of [[South Park]]'s most loved character, containing twelve uncensored episodes. "[[Tonsil Trouble]]", "[[Eek, A Penis!]]" and "[[Super Fun Time]]" were released for the first time on DVD. The set was released in a hardbound book-format that resembles the cover of the bible. The British release comes in a standard size DVD case and includes these items as PDF extras on the DVD-rom. "[[The Tale of Scrotie McBoogerballs]]" was released for the first time on DVD. On [[Netflix]], it is called ''A Very BUTTERY Collection''. It was the first time any episode had been released in HD, or Widescreen. The promotion only lasted two weeks, and was restricted to certain countries. On March 20, 2007, Best Buy continued the promotion, this time offering the episode on HD DVD, free with the purchase of any Xbox 360 or HD DVD System. {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Tomb Raider'' media|noerror}} '''''Tomb Raider''''' is a [[media franchise]] consisting of [[action-adventure game]]s, comic books, novels, theme park rides, and [[film]]s, centring on the adventures of the female [[fictional character|fictional]] British archaeologist [[Lara Croft]]. Since the release of the original ''[[Tomb Raider (1996 video game)|Tomb Raider]]'' in 1996, the series developed into a [[Media franchise|franchise]] of the [[Tomb Raider|same name]], and Lara went on to become a major icon of the video game industry. The ''[[Guinness Book of World Records]]'' has recognised Lara Croft as the "Most Successful Human Videogame Heroine" in 2006. Six games in the series were [[video game developer|developed]] by [[Core Design]], and the latest four by [[Crystal Dynamics]]. The games were first published by [[Eidos Interactive]]; Eidos became part of [[Square Enix]] on 22 April 2009. Square Enix owns the rights to the ''Tomb Raider'' trademark and characters of the franchise.{{cite web |url=http://www.neoseeker.com/news/10546-square-enix-reviews-franchise-sales-data-after-eidos-acquisition/ |title=Square Enix reviews franchise sales data after Eidos acquisition |accessdate=2009-04-28 |work=neoseeker.com |date=23 April 2009}} Three films, ''[[Lara Croft: Tomb Raider]]'', ''[[Lara Croft: Tomb Raider – The Cradle of Life]]'' and ''[[Tomb Raider (film)|Tomb Raider]]'', have been produced. The first two star American actress [[Angelina Jolie]] as Lara Croft, the third Swedish actress [[Alicia Vikander]].https://variety.com/2016/film/news/alicia-vikander-tomb-raider-lara-croft-1201753114/ The ''Tomb Raider'' video games have together sold over 45 million units,{{cite web |url=http://www.tombraiderchronicles.com/headlines3410.html |title=UNDERWORLD SET FOR CHRISTMAS DEBUT |accessdate=2009-03-23 |work=tombraiderchronicles.com |date=2008-02-29}}{{cite web |url=http://www.developmag.com/interviews/302/IP-Profile-Tomb-Raider |title=IP Profile: Tomb Raider |accessdate=2009-03-23 |work=developmag.com |date=2008-11-14}} making it one of the [[List of best-selling video games|best-selling video game]] series of all time.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/japan-dominates-best-selling-games-franchise-list |title=Japan dominates best-selling games franchise list |accessdate=2009-03-23 |work=gamesindustry.biz |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |date=2007-01-11}} ==Overview== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%;" |- ! PlayStation 4, [[PlayStation Vita]], [[macOS]], [[Linux]] (2016) |} ===''The Tomb Raider Trilogy''=== {{Infobox video game | title = The Tomb Raider Trilogy | italic title = no | collapsible = yes | state = collapsed | image = | caption = European cover art with the Classics HD logo. | developer = [[Crystal Dynamics]],
[[Buzz Monkey Software]] (port) | publisher = [[Eidos Interactive]] | series = ''[[Tomb Raider]]'' | platforms = [[PlayStation 3]] | released = {{vgrelease|EU|25 March 2011|NA|22 March 2011|AUS|31 March 2011}} | genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }} ''The Tomb Raider Trilogy'' is a collection of the three second era ''Tomb Raider'' games: ''Tomb Raider: Legend'', ''Tomb Raider: Anniversary'' and ''Tomb Raider: Underworld''. It was released on 22 March 2011 in North America and 25 March 2011 in Europe exclusively on [[PlayStation 3]] as part of the [[Classics HD]] line.{{cite web | url = http://uk.ps3.ign.com/articles/114/1140977p1.html | title = Tomb Raider Trilogy Confirmed | first = Jim | last = Reilly | date = 19 December 2010 | accessdate = 21 December 2010 | publisher = IGN}} The games were originally developed by [[Crystal Dynamics]], in association with [[Buzz Monkey Software]] and [[Nixxes Software BV]], and were [[Porting|ported]] to the PS3 by Buzz Monkey Software.{{cite web | url = http://www.computerandvideogames.com/291641/features/what-does-it-take-to-remake-a-ps2-game-in-hd-for-ps3/ | title = What does it take to remake a PS2 game in HD for PS3? | date = 5 March 2011 | accessdate = 5 March 2011 | publisher = [[Computer and Video Games]]}} The collection includes the [[PlayStation 2]] versions of ''Legend'' and ''Anniversary'' remastered in high definition plus ''Underworld'', which was previously released on the PS3 in 2008, all on one [[Blu-ray Disc]]. Also included is [[PlayStation Network#Trophies|PlayStation Network Trophy]] support, bonus Lara Croft and Viking Thrall avatars for use in [[PlayStation Home]], a theme pack for the [[XrossMediaBar]] and making-of videos.{{cite web | url = http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=280965 | title = Tomb Raider Trilogy PS3 Revealed | first = Mike | last = Jackson | date = 19 December 2010 | accessdate = 21 December 2010 | publisher = [[Computer and Video Games]]}}{{cite web | url = http://uk.ps3.ign.com/articles/114/1142819p1.html | title = Tomb Raider Trilogy Dated for PS3 | first = Matt | last = Wales | date = 6 January 2011 | accessdate = 6 January 2011 | publisher = IGN}} The two downloadable episodes available for the Xbox 360 version of ''Underworld'' are not included, and Crystal Dynamics has no current plans to make them available on PS3. ''The Angel of Darkness'', the first ''Tomb Raider'' game to be released on the PS2, is also not included in the collection as it was developed by [[Core Design]] rather than Crystal Dynamics and has no relation to the story told in ''Legend'', ''Anniversary'' and ''Underworld''. ===''Level Editor''=== The ''[[Tomb Raider Chronicles#Tomb Raider Level Editor|Tomb Raider Level Editor]]'', Room Editor, is a tool released by Eidos Interactive with the video game ''Tomb Raider Chronicles'' in late 2000. Later, it was made available free to download from the Internet. Since then it has enabled players to design new levels of their own, set in locations from the original games or in new locations. ===''The Action Adventure''=== An interactive DVD was released by Bright Entertainment under license from Eidos in 2006, called ''Tomb Raider: The Action Adventure''. The game takes advantage of standard DVD player audiovisual capabilities, and the remote control. It has puzzles and action elements, while the story is based on ''The Angel of Darkness''. ==Films== There were initially two film adaptations made in the early 2000s that starred [[Angelina Jolie]] as Lara Croft: ''[[Lara Croft: Tomb Raider]]'' in 2001 and its sequel, ''[[Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle of Life|The Cradle of Life]]'', in 2003. While both films were financially successful, neither of them were well-received by critics. A reboot starring [[Alicia Vikander]] as Lara Croft was released on 16 March 2018, which in turn was better received.{{cite news|title=IMAX and Warner Bros. Extend Deal to Include 12 More Films|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/777749-imax-and-warner-bros-extend-deal-to-include-12-more-films#/slide/1|accessdate=October 22, 2016|work=ComingSoon.net|date=October 19, 2016}} A short film called ''Tomb Raider: The Trilogy'' was produced in 1998 by Silver Films for the ''Tomb Raider III'' launch party, the film was not screened outside the event at the [[Natural History Museum, London|Natural History Museum]] in London. Producer Janey de Nordwall, who recently found the original digibeta tape, released the short film on the ''Tomb Raider'' YouTube page in 2016.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=91SoddPBJG8 Tomb Raider: The Trilogy (1998)]{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/4/24/11497950/tomb-raider-the-trilogy-video-anniversary|title=Never-seen Lara Croft short film kicks off Tomb Raider's 20th anniversary celebration|website=Polygon|last=Good|first=Owen S.|date=24 April 2016}} Lara Croft makes a minor appearance in the 2018 film ''[[Ready Player One (film)|Ready Player One]]''.{{cite web|last1=Mccreesh|first1=Louise|title=Ready Player One's second trailer drops in Lara Croft, King Kong and DC Easter eggs|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/news/a845132/ready-player-one-trailer-easter-eggs/|website=DigitalSpy|accessdate=24 February 2018}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" width=99% |+ Feature films ! Film ! Release date ! Director(s) ! Screenwriter(s) ! Story by ! Producer(s) ! Cooper, [[Mike Werb]], [[Michael Colleary]], Simon West | [[Lawrence Gordon (producer)|Lawrence Gordon]], [[Lloyd Levin]], [[Colin Wilson (film producer)|Colin Wilson]] | rowspan="2" | [[Paramount Pictures]] |- ! scope=row style="text-align:left"|''[[Lara Croft: Tomb Raider – The Cradle of Life]]'' | style="text-align:left"|{{Start date|df=y|2003|7|25}} | [[Jan de Bont]] | Dean Georgaris | [[Steven E. de Souza]], [[James V. Hart]] | Lawrence Gordon, Lloyd Levin |- ! colspan="7" style="background-color:#CEE0F2;" | Reboot |- ! scope=row style="text-align:left"|''[[Tomb Raider (film)|Tomb Raider]]'' | style="text-align:left"|{{Start date|df=y|2018|3|16}} | [[Roar Uthaug]] | Geneva Robertson-Dworet, Alastair Siddons | [[Evan Daugherty]], Geneva Robertson-Dworet | [[Graham King]] | [[Warner Bros.]] |- |} ===''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider'' (2001)=== {{Main|Lara Croft: Tomb Raider}} ===''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider – The Cradle of Life'' (2003)=== {{Main|Lara Croft: Tomb Raider – The Cradle of Life}} ===''Tomb Raider'' (2018)=== {{Main|Tomb Raider (film)}} Rumours of a third film adaptation appeared in 2007, and it was announced in 2009.{{cite video |people=[[Toby Gard|Gard, Toby]]; Smith, Jeremy Heath; [[Ian Livingstone|Livingstone, Ian]] (interviews); [[Keeley Hawes|Hawes, Keeley]] (narrator) |title=Unlock the Past: A Retrospective Tomb Raider Documentary |medium=Tomb Raider Anniversary Bonus DVD |publisher=[[Eidos Interactive]] / [[GameTap#GameTap TV|GameTap]] |date=2007 }} Also known as ''Ten Years of Tomb Raider: A GameTap Retrospective''{{Cite journal| journal = [[PlayStation: The Official Magazine]]| publisher = [[Future plc|Future Publishing]]|date=November 2009| issue = 25| title = Hollywood Remains Game Crazy| page = 57| author =Gaudiosi, John}} The film rights were acquired by [[GK Films]] in 2011, and in 2015 it was confirmed that a director was attached to the project, and that it would be developed by GK Films, Warner Bros. and MGM. The film is a reboot, showing Lara's first adventure and is based on the 2013 video game with Lara searching for her father.{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2015-11/18/tomb-raider-movie-reboot|title=Tomb Raider movie reboot sets writer and director|author=Kamen, Matt|work=[[Wired (website)|Wired]]|date=18 November 2015|accessdate=5 December 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120022830/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2015-11/18/tomb-raider-movie-reboot|archivedate=20 November 2015|deadurl=no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/03/05/tomb-raider-movie-inspired-by-new-games-says-director|title=TOMB RAIDER MOVIE INSPIRED BY NEW GAMES, SAYS DIRECTOR|website=IGN|last=Nicholson|first=Max|date=4 March 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.heyuguys.com/tomb-raider-reboot-storyline-alicia-vikander/|title=Exclusive: Producer Graham King confirms Tomb Raider reboot storyline|website=Hey U Guys|last=Sztypuljak|first=David|date=22 November 2016}} On 28 April 2016, it was announced by Variety that [[Alicia Vikander]] had been cast as Lara Croft in the reboot.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/alicia-vikander-tomb-raider-lara-croft-1201753114/|title=Alicia Vikander to Play Lara Croft in ‘Tomb Raider’ Reboot|work=Variety|last=Kroll|first=Justin|date=28 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/alicia-vikander-cast-as-lara-croft-in-tomb-raider-reboot-1201746253/|title=Alicia Vikander Cast As Lara Croft In ‘Tomb Raider’|website=Deadline Hollywood|last=Jaafar|first=Ali|date=28 April 2016}} On 7 December 2016, Variety reported that [[Walton Goggins]] had been cast as the film's villain. He told Collider that his character is confused, angry, and desperate. He later called the plot "''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]'' meets a genre version of the [[Joseph Conrad]] novel ''[[Victory: An Island Tale]]''".{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/tomb-raider-casts-walton-goggins-villain-alicia-vikander-1201886922/|title=‘Tomb Raider’ Reboot Casts Walton Goggins as Villain Opposite Alicia Vikander (EXCLUSIVE)|work=Variety|last=Kroll|first=Justin|date=7 December 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Sheridan|first1=Connor|title=Tomb Raider reboot movie is like Raiders of the Lost Ark according to bad guy actor Walton Goggins|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/tomb-raider-reboot-movie-is-like-raiders-of-the-lost-ark-according-to-bad-guy-actor-walton-goggins/|website=gamesradar.com|publisher=Future plc|accessdate=20 December 2016|date=13 December 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/tomb-raider-movie-walton-goggins-villain/|title=‘Tomb Raider’: Walton Goggins on His "Confused", "Angry", and "Desperate" Villain|website=Collider|last=Goldberg|first=Matt|date=27 December 2016}} On 11 January 2017, Variety reports that [[Daniel Wu]] is cast as Lu Ren, a ship captain who will join forces with the adventurous Lara Croft on her quest to find her father.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/tomb-raider-reboot-daniel-wu-1201958245/|title=‘Tomb Raider’ Reboot Adds ‘Into the Badlands’ Star Daniel Wu (EXCLUSIVE)|work=Variety|last=Kroll|first=Justin|date=11 January 2017}} The film was scheduled to start filming in January 2017, with a release date of 16 March 2018.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/tomb-raider-release-date-alicia-vikander-1201810114/|title=Alicia Vikander’s ‘Tomb Raider’ Gets 2018 Release Date|work=Variety|last=McNary|first=Dave|date=7 July 2016}} Filming began on 23 January 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/production-begins-new-tomb-raider-movie-1956664|title=Production officially begins on the new ‘Tomb Raider’ movie|work=[[NME]]|last=Moore|first=Sam|date=23 January 2017|accessdate=20 December 2017}} Adrian Askarieh told IGN in an interview that he may oversee a film universe with ''[[Just Cause (video game series)#Film|Just Cause]]'', ''[[Hitman: Agent 47#Future|Hitman]]'', ''[[Tomb Raider (reboot)|Tomb Raider]]'', ''[[Deus Ex (series)#Related media|Deus Ex]]'' and ''[[Thief (series)#Film|Thief]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/09/09/just-cause-movie-will-take-cues-from-just-cause-3|title=Just Cause Movie Will Take Cues from Just Cause [[CinemaScore]] |- | style="text-align:left;"| ''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider'' | 20% (157 reviews){{cite web|title=Lara Croft - Tomb Raider (2001)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/lara_croft_tomb_raider|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]]|accessdate=18 March 2018}} | 33 (31 reviews){{cite web|title=Lara Croft: Tomb Raider Reviews|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/lara-croft-tomb-raider|website=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=18 March 2018}} | {{ntsh|85}}B{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemascore.com/|title=CinemaScore|publisher=[[CinemaScore|cinemascore.com]]|accessdate=18 March 2018}} |- | style="text-align:left;"| ''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider – The Cradle of Life'' | 25% (171 reviews){{cite web|title=Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/lara_croft_tomb_raider_the_cradle_of_life|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]]|accessdate=18 March 2018}} | 43 (34 reviews){{cite web|title=Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle of Life Reviews|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/lara-croft-tomb-raider-the-cradle-of-life|website=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=18 March 2018}} | {{ntsh|80}}B- |- | style="text-align:left;"| ''Tomb Raider'' | 49% (236 reviews){{cite web|title=Tomb Raider (2018)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/tomb_raider_2018|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]]|accessdate=17 April 2018}} | 48 (53 reviews){{cite web|title=Tomb Raider Reviews|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/tomb-raider|website=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=17 April 2018}} | {{ntsh|85}}B |} ==Television== {{Main|Revisioned: Tomb Raider Animated Series}} In 2007, an animated series based on the character was produced and broadcast by [[GameTap]] as part of a series of re-imaginings of popular video game series. Titled ''[[Revisioned: Tomb Raider Animated Series|Revisioned: Tomb Raider]]'', the series ran between May and June 2007. Multiple noted animators and writers were involved with the series, including [[Peter Chung]], [[Warren Ellis]], [[Gail Simone]] and [[Jim Lee]].{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/news/gametap-announces-tomb-raider-retrospective|title=GameTap Announces Tomb Raider Retrospective|author=Kollar, Philip|website=[[1UP.com]]|date=17 May 2007|accessdate=18 November 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6d8jEHUab?url=http://www.1up.com/news/gametap-announces-tomb-raider-retrospective|archivedate=18 November 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} While the production team had great creative freedom, they were given a basic guideline for the character by the developers so that Lara would not do anything out of character.{{cite web|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2007/07/30/sdcc-07-revisioned-tomb-raider-panel|title=SDCC 07: Revisioned: Tomb Raider Panel|author=Canning, Robert|website=IGN|date=30 July 2007|accessdate=5 December 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151205112218/http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/07/30/sdcc-07-revisioned-tomb-raider-panel|archivedate=5 December 2015|deadurl=no}} ==Soundtracks== Several soundtrack albums have been released over the course of the franchise's history. Initially, music from the game was only released on promotional samplers. However, the 2013 reboot and its 2015 sequel received full soundtrack releases. Additionally, there has been at least one album release for each of the three ''Tomb Raider'' films. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Composer(s) ! Notes |- | 1999 | ''Tomb Raider: Toutes Les Musiques'' | [[Nathan McCree]] | Promotional release included with the French magazine ''Total Play'', issue 14. Includes music from ''Tomb Raider'', ''II'' and ''III''.{{cite web |title=Tomb Raider: Toutes Les Musiques (Total Play Magazine)|author=Game-ost.com |url=http://www.game-ost.com/albums/1748/tomb_raider_-_toutes_les_musiques/}} |- | rowspan="2" | 2001 | ''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider – Original Motion Picture Soundtrack'' | Various artists | |- | ''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider – Original Motion Picture Score'' | [[Graeme Revell]] | |- | rowspan="2" | 2003 | ''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider – The Cradle of Life (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)'' | Various artists |- | ''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider – The Cradle of Life (Original Motion Picture Score)'' | [[Alan Silvestri]] | |- | 2002/03 | ''[[Tomb Raider: The Angel of Darkness#Music|Tomb Raider: The Angel of Darkness (Collector's Edition) Soundtrack]]'' | [[Peter Connelly]], Martin Iveson | Promotional album released on a bonus DVD with ''Tomb Raider: The Angel of Darkness'' in 2002 and as a standalone CD album in 2003. |- | 2007 | ''[[Tomb Raider: Anniversary#Music|Tomb Raider: Anniversary (Collector's Edition) Soundtrack]]'' | [[Troels Brun Folmann]] | Promotional album released with the ''Tomb Raider: Anniversary'' Collector's Edition, which includes music from ''[[Tomb Raider: Legend]]''. |- | 2008 | ''[[Tomb Raider: Underworld#Music|Tomb Raider: Underworld (Limited Edition) Soundtrack]]'' | [[Colin O'Malley]] | Promotional album featured on ''Tomb Raider: Underworld'''s limited edition release. |- | 2013 | ''[[Tomb Raider (2013 video game)#Music|Tomb Raider – Original Soundtrack]]'' | [[Jason Graves]] | |- | 2015 | ''Rise of the Tomb Raider – Original Game Soundtrack'' | [[Bobby Tahouri]] | |- | 2018 | ''Tomb Raider – Original Motion Picture Soundtrack'' | [[Junkie XL|Tom Holkenborg]] | Soundtrack album for the 2018 reboot film. |} ==Comics== {{Main|Tomb Raider (comics)}} Beginning in 1997, Lara Croft was featured in multiple comics produced by [[Top Cow Productions]]. Her first appearance is a cameo in ''[[Witchblade]]''. She later appeared in a [[Tomb Raider (comics)|titular comic book series]] which ran for fifty issues from 1999 to 2005. An attempt by Top Cow to restart the comic in 2007 stalled due to licensing issues.{{Cite journal| journal = [[Official U.S. PlayStation Magazine]]| publisher = [[Ziff Davis]]| title = Spin: Toon Raider| page = 50| issue = 71|date=August 2003}}{{cite web| url = http://www.topcow.com/comics/25/all| title = All Tomb Raider Issues |website=topcow.com | publisher = [[Top Cow Productions]]| accessdate = 12 February 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080617102124/http://www.topcow.com/comics/25/all| archivedate = 17 June 2008|deadurl=yes}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2457165/video-game-comics/|title=Our Giant Guide to Video Game Comics|author=John, Tracey |website=mtv.com |publisher=MTV|date=26 June 2008|accessdate=5 December 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151204213218/http://www.mtv.com/news/2457165/video-game-comics/|archivedate=4 December 2015|deadurl=no}} A new comic book series began in 2014, set within the 2013 reboot's continuity and bridging the narrative gap between the reboot and its sequel.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/a-new-tomb-raider-comic-shows-whats-next-for-lara-crof-838044972|title=A New Tomb Raider Comic Shows What's Next for Lara Croft After Hit Game|author=Narcisse, Evan|website=Kotaku|date=19 July 2013|accessdate=20 July 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150616192025/http://kotaku.com/a-new-tomb-raider-comic-shows-whats-next-for-lara-crof-838044972|archivedate=16 June 2015|deadurl=no}} ==Novels== Four official novels have also been written. The first three, set within the original timeline, were published between 2003 and 2005. The first novel, ''The Amulet of Power'', was set after the events of ''The Last Revelation'', while its sequels ''The Lost Cult'' and ''The Man of Bronze'' are set after the first novel.{{cite book| title = Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Amulet of Power| year = 2003| publisher = Ballantine| isbn = 978-0-345-46171-1| author = Resnick, Mike}}{{cite book| title = Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Man of Bronze| author = Gardner, James| authorlink = James Alan Gardner| publisher = [[Random House]]| year = 2004|isbn = 978-0-345-46173-5}}{{cite book| title = Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Lost Cult| year = 2004| publisher = Random House| isbn = 978-0-345-46172-8|author=Knight, E. E.| authorlink = E. E. Knight}} Another novel set within the 2013 reboot timeline, ''Tomb Raider: The Ten Thousand Immortals'', was published in 2014 as a continuation of the original story.{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/7/1/5861198/tomb-raider-the-ten-thousand-immortals-novel-release-date|title='Tomb Raider: The Ten Thousand Immortals' novel continues reboot's story Oct. 20|author=Sarker, Samit|website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=1 July 2014|accessdate=5 December 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6dY9jFl1Q?url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/7/1/5861198/tomb-raider-the-ten-thousand-immortals-novel-release-date|archivedate=5 December 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} A fifth book, titled ''Lara Croft and the Blade of Gwynnever'', also written by Dan Abnett and Nik Vincent was published in late 2016, and is a stand-alone adventure.{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/25745759-lara-croft-and-the-blade-of-gwynnever |title=Lara Croft and the Blade of Gwynnever by Dan Abnett |website=[[Goodreads]] |date= |accessdate=20 December 2017}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Knight]] |- | ''The Man of Bronze'' | [[James Alan Gardner]] |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2014 | ''Tomb Raider: The Ten Thousand Immortals'' | [[Dan Abnett]], Nik Vincent | [[Dorling Kindersley#BradyGames|Brady Games]] |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2016 | ''Lara Croft and the Blade of Gwynnever'' | Dan Abnett | [[Prima Games]] |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.tombraider.com/}} {{Tomb Raider series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Tomb Raider Media}} [[Category:Tomb Raider]] [[Category:Media by franchise]]

'''Luis Daniel Silva''' (born in [[Havana|Habana]], 9 October 1978) is a [[Cuba]]n comedian known for his television program ''Vivir del cuento'' (roughly live by the story") and his character '''Pánfilo.'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/espanol/2014/12/09/humor-abre-paso-la-critica-social-en-cuba/|title=Humor abre paso a la crítica social en Cuba|access-date=2016-03-20|date=2014-12-09|language=|website=[[Fox News Latino]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160402054436/http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/espanol/2014/12/09/humor-abre-paso-la-critica-social-en-cuba/|archivedate=2016-04-02|df=}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.telesurtv.net/news/Panfilo-habla-con-Obama-20160319-0030.html|title=El gran humorista cubano Pánfilo habla con Obama|access-date=2016-03-20|date=19 March 2016|website=[[TeleSUR]]}}</ref> In March 2016, he filmed a sketch with US President [[Barack Obama]] in which Pánfilo calls the [[White House]] and talks with Obama about his [[United States–Cuban Thaw|visit to Cuba]].<ref name=":0"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://elcomercio.pe/mundo/actualidad/obama-apela-al-humor-ganarse-cubanos-video-noticia-1887735|title=Obama apela al humor para ganarse a los cubanos|access-date=2016-03-20|date=19 March 2016|website=[[El Comercio (Perú)|El Comercio]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telemundo.com/noticias/2016/03/19/que-bola-obama-bromea-con-humorista-cubano-panfilo|title=¿Qué bolá? Obama bromea con humorista cubano Pánfilo|access-date=2016-03-20|date=19 March 2016|website=[[Telemundo]]}}</ref>

[[File:The Best Moonwalk Ever, The Best Michael Jackson performance.webm|thumb|The moonwalk]] The '''moonwalk''' is a dance move in which the dancer moves backwards while seemingly walking forwards.<ref>Banes, Sally. ''Writing Dancing in the Age of Postmodernism'', Wesleyan University Press, 1994, p. 139.</ref> A [[popping]] move, the moonwalk became popular around the world after [[Michael Jackson]] performed it during a performance of "[[Billie Jean]]" on ''[[Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever]],'' broadcast May 16, 1983.<ref name="Time Specials">{{Citation | url = http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/completelist/0,29569,1907409,00.html | chapter = | title = Michael Jackson 1958-2009. TIME looks back on the King of Pop's life and Career | work = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | page = 13 | accessdate = February 1, 2012 | quote = We first worked with him in 1980, but he did not do the moonwalk publicly until 1983 [on Motown's 25th-anniversary TV special].}}</ref> It became his signature move.<ref>Suddath, Claire. [http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1907320,00.html "How to Moonwalk like Michael"], ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', June 25, 2009.</ref><ref name=Thriller25>''[[Thriller 25]]: The Book'', ML Publishing Group Ltd, 2008. {{ISBN|978-0-9768891-9-9}}.</ref>
==Technique== An [[illusion]] is involved in creating the appearance of the dancer gliding backwards. Initially, the front foot is held flat on the ground, while the back foot is in a [[tiptoe]] position. The flat front foot remains on the ground but is slid lightly and smoothly backward past the tip-toe back foot. What is now the front foot is lowered flat, while the back foot is raised into the tiptoe position. These steps are repeated over and over creating the illusion that the dancer is being pulled backwards by an unseen force while trying to walk forward. Variations of this move allow moonwalking to appear to glide forward, sideways, or even in a circle.
==History== [[File:Minnie the Moocher (1932).webm|thumb|thumbtime=26|start=26|end=67|[[Cab Calloway]] executed steps similar to the moonwalk (sidewalk or toe stand) as early as 1932.]] [[File:Michael Jackson ao vivo 1993.jpg|thumb|[[Michael Jackson]] popularized and named the moonwalk in 1983.]]
There are many recorded instances of the moonwalk; similar steps are reported as far back as 1932, used by [[Cab Calloway]].<ref>Pagett, Matt. ''The Best Dance Moves in the World - Ever!'' Chronicle Books, 2008, p. 72.</ref> In 1985, Calloway said that the move was called "The Buzz" when he and others performed it in the 1930s.<ref name=DiLorenzo1985>{{cite journal|last=DiLorenzo |first=Kris |date=April 1985 |title=The Arts. Dance: Michael Jackson did not invent the Moonwalk |journal=The Crisis |volume=92 |number=4 |issn=0011-1422 |page=143|quote=Shoot ... We did that back in the '30s! Only it was called The Buzz back then.}}</ref><ref>{{cite video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jCOvG_vGzRc |title=Cab Calloway in 1932 film "The Big Broadcast" |publisher=YouTube}}</ref>
In 1944, [[Judy Garland]] and [[Margaret O'Brien]] featured something like the move in their performance of "Under the Bamboo Tree" in ''[[Meet Me in St. Louis]],'' though their performance lacks the illusion created by the genuine moonwalk.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s8qpMcrEtTg |title=Under The Bamboo Tree - Judy Garland (Meet Me In St. Louis) |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-07-06 |accessdate=2014-06-18}}</ref>
In the 1950s, [[Dick Van Dyke]] performed a similar variation of the moonwalk and [[Camel Walk#1950s/1960s Variant|camel walk]] in his [[sketch comedy|comedy routine]] called "Mailing A Letter On A Windy Corner".
In 1955, it was recorded in a performance by tap dancer [[Bill Bailey (dancer)|Bill Bailey]]. He performs a tap routine, and at the end, backslides into the wings.<ref>{{cite video |url=https://archive.org/details/BillBailey |title=Bill Bailey in 1955}}</ref> The French [[mime]] artist [[Marcel Marceau]] used it throughout his career (from the 1940s through the 1980s), as part of the drama of his mime routines. In Marceau's "Walking Against the Wind" routine, he pretends to be pushed backwards by a gust of wind.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/grand-master-of-mime-marcel-marceau-dies-1.644639| accessdate=2007-09-23 | title=Grand master of mime, Marcel Marceau, dies | agency=Associated Press | date=23 September 2007 | work=CBC News}}</ref>
In 1958, Mexican dancer-comedian [[Adalberto Martinez]] "Resortes" also performed the moonwalk in the film ''Colegio de Verano'' (Summer School).
In a November 1969 episode of ''[[H.R. Pufnstuf]]'', Judy the Frog teaches everyone a new dance called "The Moonwalk", which includes two instances of a stationary moonwalk.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tressugar.com/Moonwalk-HR-Pufnstuf-1093896|title=Did Jacko Jack the Moonwalk?}}</ref>
1972 Lucie Arnaz in Here's Lucy Episode 9 of Season 5 "Lucy and Jim Bailey" Lucie does the Moonwalk whilst singing "Fever" with Jim Bailey
Choreographer [[Bob Fosse]] moonwalks in his role as the Snake in the 1974 film "[[The Little Prince (1974 film)|The Little Prince]]". <ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eUTEhEPONgc | title=sssssSnake in the Grasssss | work=YouTube.com | accessdate=September 11, 2008}}</ref>
It has also a been acknowledged that the professional wrestlers [[Michael Hayes (wrestler)|Michael "Pure Sexy" Hayes]], [[Terry Gordy]], and [[Buddy Roberts]] started doing the moonwalk as their trademark ring entrance by 1979 when they formed a wrestling stable known as [[The Fabulous Freebirds]].<ref name="Birds">{{cite book | author=Greg Oliver and Steve Johnson | title= The Pro Wrestling Hall of Fame: The Tag Teams | publisher=ECW Press | chapter= Top 20: 7 The Fabulous Freebirds | pages= 46–51 | year=2005| isbn=978-1-55022-683-6}}</ref>
[[James Brown]] used the move<ref name="Inglis" /> and can be seen performing it in the 1980 film ''[[The Blues Brothers (film)|The Blues Brothers]]''. In 1981 in the promotional single and music video ''[[Crosseyed and Painless]]'' by new wave band [[Talking Heads]], authentic street dancers, picked by David Byrne, are featuring, including Stephen "Skeeter Rabbit" Nichols doing the moonwalk.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Zrkf65GmwE | title=Talking Heads - Crosseyed and Painless - Official Original Video, 1981 | work=YouTube.com | accessdate=August 5, 2011}}</ref> It reached to 20 on the US dance charts. Another early moonwalker was [[Popping|popper]] and singer [[Jeffrey Daniel]], who moonwalked in a performance of [[Shalamar]]'s "A Night To Remember" on ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' in the UK in 1982<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=END_WYdf8pw | title=A Night to Remember, Shalamar, Top of the Pops, 1982 | work=YouTube.com | accessdate=October 25, 2012}}</ref> and was known to perform backslides in public performances (including weekly ''[[Soul Train]]'' episodes) as far back as 1974. Michael Jackson was a fan of Jeffrey Daniel's dancing and would eventually seek him out.
Also in 1982, [[Debbie Allen]] performs a moonwalk during a scene with [[Gwen Verdon]] in Season 1, Episode 10 ("Come One, Come All") of the TV series ''[[Fame (1982 TV series)|Fame]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KFr4tBnXJ38 |title=Fame: Season 1 Episode 10 - "Evolution of Dance" Original Air Date: March 11th 1982 |publisher=YouTube.com |date=2006-09-29 |accessdate=2014-06-18}}</ref>
In ''[[Flashdance]]'', the move was used in the B-boy scene, where Rock Steady Crew's Mr. Freeze (Marc Lemberger), with an umbrella prop, [[mime]]d the wind blowing him backward as he first walks forward, fighting the wind, then starts moonwalking backwards. Mr. Freeze's version was also shown in the first hip hop movie ''Wild Style'' and [[Malcolm McLaren]] film clip "[[Buffalo Gals (Malcolm McLaren song)|Buffalo Gals]]".<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RME_Qqaju9w ''Buffalo Gals''] (first 12 seconds sample) at [[YouTube]]</ref>
[[Jeffrey Daniel]] taught Michael Jackson the moonwalk. Jackson saw Daniel do the moonwalk dance on ''Soul Train'' and had his manager call ''Soul Train'' to introduce him to the dancer. Daniel was touring with Shalamar at the time so Cooley Jackson and Caszper Candidate went to teach Jackson. However, Jackson was not able to pick up and master the technique until Daniel returned from tour and worked with him.{{Citation needed|date=July 2015}} The dance was popularized in 1983 when Jackson performed it during a television special, ''[[Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever]]'', on March 25 of that year. Dressed in his [[Trademark look|signature]] black trousers, silver socks, silver shirt, black-sequined jacket, sequined glove, and black fedora, Jackson spun around, posed, and began moonwalking. Music critic Ian Inglis later wrote that Jackson encapsulated a long tradition of [[African-American dance]] movements in that one performance.<ref name=Inglis>Inglis, Ian. ''Performance and popular music'', Ashgate Publishing, 2006, p. 122.</ref> Moonwalking received widespread attention, and from then on, the moonwalk became Jackson's signature move for his song "[[Billie Jean]]". [[Nelson George]] said that Jackson's rendition "combined [[Jackie Wilson]]'s athleticism with James Brown's [[camel walk]]". Michael Jackson's autobiography was titled ''[[Moonwalk (book)|Moonwalk]]'', and he also starred in a 1988 film titled ''[[Moonwalker]]''.
In the 1984 movie ''[[Streets of Fire]]'', actor and performer [[Stoney Jackson]] executed a moonwalk as the leader of a fictional group, The Sorels, who lip-synced to the [[Dan Hartman]] song "[[I Can Dream About You]]".
[[Alexei Kovalev]] has been known for using the moonwalk in his [[National Hockey League]] career.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mE7yOppnwHQ | title=Youtube "Alex Kovalev Moonwalk on ice" | accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> He performed the move after scoring a goal on February 7, 2001, and on January 3, 2010. Kovalev moonwalked onto the ice after being named one of the stars of the game and again after scoring in a 2008 celebrity charity soccer game.
In 2018, [[Alessia Cara]] briefly used the moonwalk in the music video for her song "Trust My Lonely."<ref>{{Citation|last=AlessiaCaraVEVO|title=Alessia Cara - Trust My Lonely|date=2018-10-04|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=149&v=uF9YayOgjRg|access-date=2018-11-14}}</ref> {{Clear}}

{{Infobox theatre | name = Municipal Theatre of Santiago, National Opera of Chile | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- ISO 639-2 code e.g. "fr" for French. If more than one, use {{lang}} instead --> | image = Teatro Municipal de Santiago de Chile.JPG | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = National Opera of Chile | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption= | address = Agustinas 794 [[Santiago Metropolitan Region]] | city = [[Santiago, Chile]] | country = | designation = | architect = | owner = | tenant = | operator = | capacity = | type = | opened = September 17, 1857 | reopened = | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | website = http://www.municipal.cl/ }}
{{Refimprove|date=December 2011}} The '''Teatro Municipal''', '''National Opera of Chile''' is the most important stage theatre and opera house in [[Santiago]], [[Chile]].
==History and overview== The Chilean government ceded a significant parcel of land in downtown Santiago to the municipality, in 1848, and an 1853 decree by President [[Manuel Montt Torres]] provided for the construction of a municipal theater in his nation's capital, by then a rapidly growing city. [[French Chilean]] architect [[Claudio Brunet des Baines]] was commissioned for its design, and its construction was entrusted to another French Chilean, [[civil engineer]] Felipe Charme de l´Isle. Brunet des Baines created a [[French Rococo and Neoclassicism|French Neoclassical]] exterior<ref name="BensonGraham2009">{{cite book|author1=Andrew Benson|author2=Melissa Graham|title=The Rough Guide to Chile|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XPr4ktEI8JEC|accessdate=10 December 2011|date=3 August 2009|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-1-4053-8381-3|page=93}}</ref> for the theater, though his 1855 death left the supervision of the design to his countryman, Lucien Henault, and to the latter's assistant, Manuel Aldunate. The new team also benefited from a collaboration with [[Charles Garnier (architect)|Charles Garnier]], the architect of the [[Opéra National de Paris]]. [[File:Santiago - Teatro Municipal (1872).jpg|thumb|left|View of the Teatro Municipal in 1872.]]
The Teatro Municipal was inaugurated on September 17, 1857,<ref name="BensonGraham2009"/> with the opera ''[[Ernani]]'' by [[Giuseppe Verdi]], performed by an Italian company brought in specially for the occasion. At the time, the theatre held 1,800 spectators, and included distinctive interior details such as a teardrop crystal chandelier. A December 8, 1870, performance by opera diva [[Carlotta Patti]] was followed by a massive fire, which practically destroyed the building. A quick response by both the local government and Chilean high society resulted in the theatre's prompt reconstruction, designed by Henault and completed on July 16, 1873. Its reinauguration was accompanied by a performance of Verdi's ''[[La forza del destino]]''.
===20th century=== The theatre went through a devastating 1906 earthquake, suffering the loss of most of its interior, and a second, serious fire in 1927, although it recovered quickly on both occasions. Following these reconstructions, the theatre's capacity was reduced to 1,500 in the main hall; however, its interior became more opulent. It was further modernized in 1952 and 1959, and numerous cultural institutions were created for the theatre during that era. The ''Santiago Philharmonic Orchestra'' was established in 1955, the Cultural Corporation of Santiago was formed to administer the center in 1957, the ''Santiago Ballet'' in 1959, and the ''Teatro Municipal Chorus'', in 1962.
The Teatro Municipal was declared a National Monument, in 1974. The theatre hosted the two editions of the [[OTI Festival]] in Chile: in [[OTI Festival 1978|1978]] and in [[OTI Festival 1986|1986]]. Renowned Chilean pianist [[Claudio Arrau]], who had left his homeland in 1941, returned for a visit in 1984, on which occasion the Claudio Arrau Salon, seating 250 spectators, was inaugurated. The stage curtain, installed in 1926, was replaced in 1995 with funds raised by offering donors a piece of the older curtain as a keepsake.
The institution continues to maintain an active repertoire, and some of its most illustrious recent international guest performers and conductors have included: names in [[ballet]] such as [[Julio Bocca]], [[Mikhail Baryshnikov]], the [[Bolshoi Ballet]] and the [[Mariinsky Ballet]]; pianists [[Claudio Arrau]], [[Valentina Igoshina]] and [[Arthur Rubinstein]], [[Vladimir Ashkenazy]] and [[Daniel Barenboim]]; violinists [[Mischa Elman]], [[Jascha Heifetz]], [[Yehudi Menuhin]], [[Gil Shaham]] and [[Isaac Stern]]; conductors [[Zubin Mehta]], [[Charles Dutoit]], [[Kurt Masur]] and [[Pierre Boulez]]; and stage performers such as [[Plácido Domingo]], Dame [[Kiri Te Kanawa]], [[Charles Aznavour]], [[Vivien Leigh]], [[Luciano Pavarotti]], [[Tito Schipa]] and [[Renée Fleming]].
==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}} '''Sources''' *[http://www.municipal.cl/detalles.asp?ca_parent=1884&in_ubicacion=1886&submenu=1885 Teatro Municipal de Santiago: Reseña Histórica {{es icon}}]
{{commons category|Teatro Municipal de Santiago (Municipal Theatre of Santiago)}}
==External links== *[http://www.municipal.cl/ Teatro Municipal: website {{es icon}}]
{{Coord|33|26|27|S|70|38|51|W|display=title}}

岐阜県美術館 |image = THE_MUSEUM_OF_FINE_ARTS%2CGIFU_1.JPG |imagesize = 200 |map_type = |map_caption = |latitude = |longitude = |established = November 3, 1982 |dissolved = |location = 4-1-22 Usa, [[Gifu, Gifu|Gifu]]
[[Gifu Prefecture]], [[Japan]] |type = [[Art museum]] |visitors = |director = |curator = |publictransit = [[Gifu Bus]] ''Kanō Danchi Line'' towards ''Ichibashi'' at either [[Gifu Station|JR Gifu Station]] or [[Meitetsu Gifu Station]] and get off at ''Gifu-ken Bijutsukan''. |website = [http://www.kenbi.pref.gifu.lg.jp Gifu Prefectural Art Museum] }} The {{nihongo|'''Museum of Fine Arts, Gifu'''|岐阜県美術館|Gifu-ken Bijutsukan}} is art museum located in the city of [[Gifu, Gifu|Gifu]], [[Gifu Prefecture]], [[Japan]].[[Louis-Frédéric|Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric]]. (2005). [https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&pg=PA671&dq= "Museums"] in ''Japan Encyclopedia'', pp. 671-673. The focus of the museum is on art and artists related to Gifu Prefecture, but the museum also collects pieces from other places in Japan and overseas.[http://www.pref.gifu.lg.jp/pref/s27213/ Museum of Fine Arts, Gifu] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613230758/http://www.pref.gifu.lg.jp/pref/s27213/ |date=2007-06-13 }}. Museum of Fine Arts, Gifu. Accessed June 5, 2007. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category-inline|Museum of Fine Arts,GIFU|Museum of Fine Arts, Gifu}} {{official website|http://www.kenbi.pref.gifu.lg.jp}} {{coord|35.401309|136.730221|type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fine Arts, Gifu}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Gifu|Museum of Fine Arts, Gifu]] [[Category:Museums in Gifu Prefecture]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in Japan]] [[Category:Art museums established in 1982]] [[Category:1982 establishments in Japan|Museum of Fine Arts, Gifu]] {{japan-museum-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Museum of Particularly Bad Art logo.jpg|right|180px|thumbnail|The logo for Museum of Particularly Bad Art. (Picture of [[Elvis]] and [[Priscilla Presley]])]] '''The Museum of Particularly Bad Art Exhibition''' (MOPBA) is an annual event held on [[Chapel Street]], [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] celebrating poor [[art]] forms, primarily in the forms of [[painting]]s and [[Sketch (drawing)|sketch]]es. MOPBA relies on a core group of art pieces owned by [[Helen Round]] but the public are invited to enter pieces that are their own or that have been found that are considered poor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/eish/kitsch-becomes-an-artform-in-australia-418024|title=Kitsch becomes an artform in Australia - IOL News|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nrk.no/kultur/er-dette-arets-verste-kunstverk_-1.7300495|title=Er dette årets verste kunstverk?|first=|last=NRK|publisher=}}</ref> The event primarily is a charity event that funds three charities within the [[City of Stonnington|Stonnington]] area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/07/16/1089694559243.html|title=Art that's no oil painting - Arts - www.theage.com.au|website=www.theage.com.au}}</ref>
==Criteria== The entries from the public are judged by meeting one point on the selection criteria. Selection points for entry of an art piece into MOPBA are:
* Completely devoid of technical skill ([[Colour]], [[Lightness (color)|tone]], [[Perspective (graphical)|perspective]] and [[shading]]); * Unusual, poor or tasteless subject matters; * Passion of the [[artist]] but is driven by an [[Amateur|uneducated hand]]; * An instinctual feeling that the art piece is poor. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20100922/world/bad-art-in-australia.327977|title=Bad art in Australia|first=Allied Newspapers|last=Ltd|publisher=}}</ref>
==History== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Gary Glitter.jpg|right|thumbnail|"No one Wants to Touch Him There." ([[Gary Glitter]]). Materials: Crushed velvet, Acrylic and Glitter.]] --> [[Image:Windsor Junkie.jpg|left|300px|thumbnail|''Windsor Junkie circa 1896'' - Itchiball Prize Winner 2005.]] The founder of MOPBA is [[Helen Round]]. In the early 1990s, ''[[Foreign Correspondent (TV series)|Foreign Correspondent]]'' reported on the [[Museum of Bad Art]] in [[Dedham, Massachusetts|Dedham]], United States. At this point of her life, Round was in the process of establishing a retail shop named "Fat Helen’s Bric a Brac shop", that was to specialise in the [[kitsch]], inane and tasteless. It was also a hobby of Round's to peruse [[op shop]]s, [[garage sale]]s and [[Market (place)|market]]s. She was inspired by what she came across in these places and commenced her pursuit of collecting and preserving the mediocre. Round started collecting in 1993.<ref>{{cite web|title=Museum of Particularly Bad Art: About|url=http://www.mopba.org/?page_id=2|accessdate=2014-08-14}}</ref><ref name="spiegel">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/reise/aktuell/kunst-in-melbourne-museum-der-haesslichkeiten-a-583180.html|title=Kunst in Melbourne: Museum der Hässlichkeiten|date=9 October 2008|publisher=|via=Spiegel Online}}</ref>
Since then, Round has collected 200 examples of original art of poor taste. Of notable fame is the original portrait of [[actor]] [[Scott Baio]] that Round located in an op shop in the suburb of [[Windsor, Victoria|Windsor]] in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/suzanne-carbone/amanda-needs-love/2005/08/02/1122748636560.html|title=Amanda needs to be loved - Carbone & Money - Opinion - theage.com.au|website=www.theage.com.au}}</ref><ref name="spiegel"/>
The Exhibition awards the Itchiball Prize to the submitted art piece that is considered by the public to be the poorest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/deepend/dreadful-art/3339714|title=Dreadful art|date=8 August 2006|website=Australian Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref> The name is a play on words and parody of the '[[Archibald Prize]]', Australia's most important [[portrait]]ure painting award.<ref>{{cite web|title=Itchyball Prize|url=http://www.mopba.org/?page_id=8|website=Museum of Particularly Bad Art|accessdate=2014-08-14}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Kitsch]] * [[Museum of Bad Art]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.mopba.org/ Official site] *[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/collectors/video/index/ Collectors — Video of Helen Round] - Episode Six, 17 March 2006 *[http://www.theage.com.au/news/arts/little-shop-of-horrors/2005/08/24/1124562915277.html 2005 Museum of Particularly Bad Art] <!--- [[WP:LR]] *[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/collectors/txt/s1625607.htm Collectors — Helen Round] *[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/07/16/1089694559243.html/ 2004 Museum of Particularly Bad Art] *[http://www.mumbaimirror.com/net/mmpaper.aspx?page=article&sectid=4&contentid=20080926200809260245481539932218f&pageno=1 Mumbai News - A good taste for bad art!] *[http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20080925/ennew_afp/australiaartoffbeat_080925051423 Kitsch becomes an artform at unique Australian painting exhibit - Yahoo! News] *[http://www.abc.net.au/arts/stories/s3028966.htm - The Museum of Particularly Bad Art]--->
{{DEFAULTSORT:Museum Of Particularly Bad Art}} [[Category:Arts in Melbourne]] [[Category:Art exhibitions in Australia]] [[Category:Exhibitions in Australia]] [[Category:Satire]] [[Category:Humour]] [[Category:Professional humor]]

{{unreferenced|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:Music of the ''Harry Potter'' films}} [[Image:John Williams tux.jpg|thumb|right|130px|John Williams, composer of the first three films and creator of ''Hedwig's Theme''.]] The '''music of the ''Harry Potter'' [[Harry Potter (film series)|film series]]''' was recorded and released in conjunction with the post-production and releases of each of the eight corresponding films. The scores were composed by [[John Williams]], [[Patrick Doyle]], [[Nicholas Hooper]], and [[Alexandre Desplat]]. Musicians credited with writing source music include [[Jarvis Cocker]], [[The Ordinary Boys]] and [[Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds]]. [[Jeremy Soule]] and [[James Hannigan]] wrote the music for the ''Harry Potter'' video games. ==Overview== {| class="wikitable" style="border:2px #aaa solid; font-size:100%;" ! Year ! Title ! Composer ! Conductor ! Orchestrator ! Orchestra |- | 2001 |[[Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film)|''Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone'']] | rowspan="3" | [[John Williams]] | John Williams | rowspan="3" | [[Conrad Pope]]
Eddie Karam | Unknown |- | 2002 | [[Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (soundtrack)|''Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets'']] | [[William Ross (composer)|William Ross]] | [[London Symphony Orchestra]] |- | 2004 | [[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (soundtrack)|''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban'']] | John Williams | Unknown |- | 2005 | [[Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (soundtrack)|''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire'']] | [[Patrick Doyle]] | [[James Shearman]] | Lawrence Ashmore
John Bell
Nicole Nevin
Brad Dechter | London Symphony Orchestra |- | 2007 | [[Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (soundtrack)|''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix'']] | rowspan="2" | [[Nicholas Hooper]] | [[Alastair King]] | Geoff Alexander
Julian Kershaw
Bradely Miles
Simon Whiteside | rowspan="2" | Chamber Orchestra of London |- | 2009 | [[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (soundtrack)|''Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince'']] | Nicholas Hooper
Alastair King | Alastair King
Jeff Atmajian
Geoff Alexander
Simon Whiteside
Daryl Griffith |- | 2010 | [[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1 (soundtrack)|''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1'']] | colspan="2" rowspan="2" | [[Alexandre Desplat]] | Alexandre Desplat
Conrad Pope
Nan Schwartz
Clifford Tasner
Jean-Pascal Beintus | rowspan="2" | London Symphony Orchestra |- | 2011 | [[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2 (soundtrack)|''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2'']] | Conrad Pope
Clifford Tasner
Jean-Pascal Beintus
Bill Newlin |} == Themes and motifs == Throughout the series, each composer created themes for particular characters, items, locations, and ideas. === First appearance in ''The Philosopher's Stone'' === {| class="wikitable" style="border:2px #aaa solid; font-size:100%;" ! Theme ! Description ! Scores heard in |- | Hedwig's Theme | The dominant theme closely identified with and used in all of the Harry Potter films. Though titled "Hedwig's Theme", it doesn't always specifically represent Hedwig, but rather the wider idea of magic and the Wizarding World. Its concert suite is frequently performed by musicians and ensembles. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'', ''The Chamber of Secrets'', ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'', ''The Goblet of Fire'', ''The Order of the Phoenix'', ''The Half-Blood Prince'', ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'', and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- | Family Portrait | Represents Harry's parents and his new family in Hogwarts. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'', ''The Chamber of Secrets'', and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' (Tracked) |- | Harry's Wondrous World | Associated with Harry and his friendships with Ron and Hermione. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'', ''The Chamber of Secrets'', and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' (Tracked) |- | Nimbus 2000 | Associated with the Nimbus 2000, flying, and mischief. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'', ''The Chamber of Secrets'', ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- | Voldemort's Theme | A two-part theme associated with the main antagonist, Lord Voldemort | ''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Philosopher's Stone | Associated with the Philosopher's Stone and used to represent Voldemort in ''The Chamber of Secrets''. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Diagon Alley | Represents Diagon Alley as a setting. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'' (album only) and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Hogwarts Forever | A thematic representation of Hogwarts | ''The Philosopher's Stone'' |- | Quidditch Fanfare | Represents the commencement of the quidditch matches. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'' |- | Christmas at Hogwarts | Associated with the arrival of winter and Christmas. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | The Dark Forest | Represents the Dark Forest as a setting. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | The Flying Keys | Represents flying magical objects and creatures such as the flying keys in the first movie or Cornish Pixies and bludger in the second movie. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | The Banquet Fanfare | Music used during banquet scenes. | ''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | The Great Hall Fanfare | Theme associated with the discovery of the amazing wizarding world. Used for the discoveries of Diagon Alley (in the movie), Hogwarts and the Great Hall (and during the sorting of Hermione). |''The Philosopher's Stone'' |- | Ron Weasley's Motif | Cute little theme used to represents the lightness of Ron. |''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Weasley's Family | Comical theme heard during family scenes, notably the train station scenes. |''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Comical Theme | Used for Hagrid's dragon and Ron's eat slugs curse. |''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Revelation Theme | Used with the first appearance of the chess board and the chamber of secrets or when Filch and Snape discover that someone was in the restricted library in the first movie. |''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Mysterious "something's coming" Theme | Heard with the first appearance of Dumbledore out of the mist, and the approche of flying car. Also used when Harry, Ron and Hermione visit Hagrid in the middle of the night. |''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Dursley's Theme | Comical theme associated with the Dursleys. |''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Ghosts' Motif | Music heard when the ghosts appear. Also used with the Moaning Myrtle's theme. |''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Invisibility Cloak Theme | Associated with the cloak and during its use in both films. |''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Fluffy's Harp | Music played by the harp in the first film. |''The Philosopher's Stone'' |- |Leaving Hogwarts |Music played when Harry gets on the train. |''The Philosopher's Stone'' and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |} === First appearance in ''The Chamber of Secrets'' === {| class="wikitable" style="border:2px #aaa solid; font-size:100%;" ! Theme ! Description ! Scores Heard in |- | Fawkes the Phoenix | Associated with Dumbledore's pet Phoenix. | ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Gilderoy Lockhart | Represents the aforementioned professor. | ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Dobby's Theme | Represents Dobby the House Elf. | ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | The Chamber of Secrets | Associated with the Chamber of Secrets as a setting. | ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Moaning Myrtle | Associated with Moaning Myrtle. | ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | The Flying Car | Represents the enchanted car used by the protagonists. | ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Spider's Theme | Eight notes theme (one for each leg) associated with Aragog's spiders. | ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Lucius Malfoy's Theme | Conspiracy theme associated with Malfoy. It is based on a similar theme heard in ''[[Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (soundtrack)|Star Wars: Attack of the Clones]]''. | ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |- | Errol the Owl | Associated with the pet owl of the Weasley family. | ''The Chamber of Secrets'' |} === First appearance in ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' === {| class="wikitable" style="border:2px #aaa solid; font-size:100%;" ! Theme ! Description ! Scores Heard in |- | Double Trouble | Works as the main thematic identity for the third score, also used in a source cue. | ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' |- | A Window to the Past | Associated with characters that have connections to Harry's parents. | ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' |- | Buckbeak's Flight | Represents Buckbeak while flying. | ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' |- | Quidditch Motif | Secondary theme used to represent Quidditch. | ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' and ''The Half-Blood Prince'' |- | Patronus Theme | Associated with the Patronus Charm. | ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' |- | Dark Omen Motif | Associated with Sirius Black in animal form. | ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' |- | Peter Pettigrew's Theme | Represents Peter Pettigrew. | ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' |} === First appearance in ''The Goblet of Fire'' === {| class="wikitable" style="border:2px #aaa solid; font-size:100%;" ! Theme ! Description ! Scores Heard in |- | Voldemort's Theme | New thematic identity for Lord Voldemort. | ''The Goblet of Fire'' and ''The Order of the Phoenix''{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RDMqSrHFX0w&index=14&list=PL2F1puva1CgsFoVFlOZhWpo1OaK7bqG5D |website=Youtube.com |accessdate=21 July 2018 |pages=42 seconds}} |- | Harry's Theme | New thematic identity for Harry. Its concert suite is entitled "Harry in Winter". | ''The Goblet of Fire'' |- | Hogwarts' Hymn | New thematic identity for Hogwarts. | ''The Goblet of Fire'' |} === First appearance in ''The Order of the Phoenix'' === {| class="wikitable" style="border:2px #aaa solid; font-size:100%;" ! Theme ! Description ! Scores Heard in |- | Professor Umbridge | Represents Hogwarts Professor Dolores Umbridge. | ''The Order of the Phoenix'' |- | Possession | Associated with Voldemort and his attempt to possess Harry. | ''The Order of the Phoenix'' and ''The Half-Blood Prince'' |- | Fireworks | Associated with the antics of Fred and George Weasley. | ''The Order of the Phoenix'' and ''The Half-Blood Prince'' |- | Dumbledore's Army | Represents Dumbledore's Army and the bonding of friends. | ''The Order of the Phoenix'' and ''The Half-Blood Prince'' (tracked) |- | The Kiss | Represents Harry's love and later his friendship | ''The Order of the Phoenix'' and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2 '' |- | Ministry of Magic | Represents the Ministry of Magic. | ''The Order of the Phoenix'' |} === First appearance in ''The Half-Blood Prince'' === {| class="wikitable" style="border:2px #aaa solid; font-size:100%;" ! Theme ! Description ! Scores Heard in |- | In Noctem | Represents Albus Dumbledore. | ''The Half-Blood Prince'' |- | Death Eater Theme | Rhythmic ostinato for Voldemort's Death Eaters. | ''The Half-Blood Prince'' |- | Malfoy's Theme | Represents Draco Malfoy and his mission. | ''The Half-Blood Prince'' |- | Slughorn's Theme | Associated with Professor Slughorn. | ''The Half-Blood Prince'' |- | Harry and Hermione | Represents Harry's friendship with Hermione. | ''The Half-Blood Prince'' |- | Dumbledore's Farewell | Associated with the deaths of Sirius Black and Albus Dumbledore. | ''The Half-Blood Prince'' and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' (tracked) |} === First appearance in ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' === {| class="wikitable" style="border:2px #aaa solid; font-size:100%;" ! Theme ! Description ! Scores Heard in |- | Obliviate | Represents the loss of innocence of Harry, Ron, and Hermione. Main identity for the movie. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- | Band of Brothers Theme (Friends Theme) | In ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'', it represents the Order of the Phoenix. In ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'', the theme is associated specifically with Neville. Also used as a theme for Ginny and Harry. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- | Voldemort's Theme | New thematic identity for Lord Voldemort. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' |- | Death Eaters | Ostinato motif representing the Death Eaters. Often played in counterpoint with Voldemort's theme. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' |- | Dumbledore Theme | New thematic identity for Dumbledore and his family. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' (Tracked) |- | Horcruxes Theme | Associated with Voldemort's horcruxes. This theme is first used for the locket in Part 1. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- |Ron's Theme or Love Theme | Theme associated with Ron and obviously as a love theme for him and Hermione. It can be heard in '''Ron Leaves''', '''Ron's Speech''' and at the end of '''Hermione's Parents''' when Ron returns in Part 1. It is reused in Part 2 during the kiss and when Hermione and Ron search for Harry during the battle (not used). | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- |Hermione's Theme |Sweet Theme associated with Hermione. This theme can be heard prominently in the first part of '''Hermione's Parents''' and at the end of '''The Dumbledores'''. It is used again during the torture scene with Bellatrix. In the Demos of the soundtrack this theme can also be heard in the track '''Traveling Montage''' when Harry and Hermione disappear after the departure of Ron (but this track is not in the final soundtrack or movie). | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' |- | Deathly Hallows | Represents the Deathly Hallows as objects. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' and ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- | Dobby's Theme | New thematic identity for Dobby. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' |- | Lovegood's Theme | Represents Xenophilius Lovegood, and is often in counterpoint with the "Deathly Hallows" theme. It is Only heard in the credits. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' |} === First appearance in ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' === {| class="wikitable" style="border:2px #aaa solid; font-size:100%;" ! Theme ! Description ! Scores Heard in |- | Lily's Theme | Associated with the memory of Harry's mother. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- | Statues | Represents the Battle of Hogwarts. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- | Battlefield | Secondary theme for the Battle of Hogwarts. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- | Severus and Lily | Represents Snape's love for Harry's mother. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |- | Resurrection Theme | Represents the Resurrection Stone and life. | ''The Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' |} == References == {{reflist}} {{Harry Potter}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Harry Potter Film Series, Music}} [[Category:Music of the Harry Potter films| ]] [[Category:Music by media franchise]] [[Category:Harry Potter lists]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/105.227.192.130|105.227.192.130]] ([[User talk:105.227.192.130|talk]]) to last revision by ThunderingTyphoons!. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
/* History */ Suncorp Super Netball uses the pure Page system.
revision.text:
The '''Page playoff system''' is a [[playoff format]] used primarily in [[softball]] and [[curling]] at the championship level, the [[Pakistan Super League]], and the [[Indian Premier League]] [[cricket]] tournament. Teams are [[Single-elimination tournament#Seeding|seed]]ed using a [[round-robin tournament]] and the top four play a mix of a [[single-elimination tournament|single-elimination]] and [[double-elimination tournament]] to determine the winner. It is identical to a four-team [[McIntyre System]] playoff, first used by the [[Australian Football League|Victorian Football League]] in Australia in 1931, originally called the '''[[Page–McIntyre system]]''', after the VFL delegate, the [[Richmond Football Club]]'s Secretary, Percy "Pip" Page, who had advocated its use.
==History== The Page playoff system was used at the Australian Rugby League Championship 1954-1972. In Australia, its most notable use today is in netball, having been adopted by [[Suncorp Super Netball]] when it began play in 2017.
The system has been used since 1990 by the [[International Softball Federation]] and its successor, the [[World Baseball Softball Confederation]], for the [[Women's Softball World Championship]] and from 1996 to 2008 at the [[Softball at the Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]].<ref name=ISF>International Softball Federation. [http://www.internationalsoftball.com/english/rules_standards/technical_venue_man.pdf Technical & Venue Manual] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061025144555/http://www.internationalsoftball.com/english/rules_standards/technical_venue_man.pdf |date=2006-10-25 }} ([[PDF]]). Retrieved March 23, 2006</ref>
Its first use in curling was by the [[Canadian Curling Association]] in the [[1995 Labatt Brier|1995 Labatt]] [[Tim Hortons Brier|Brier]],<ref name=LFP>Dalla Costa, Morris (March 3, 2006). [http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Curling/TournamentOfHearts/2006/03/03/1471245-sun.html]. ''[[London Free Press via Canoe]]''.</ref> the men's championship, and was adopted the next year at the [[1996 Scott Tournament of Hearts|1996]] [[Scotties Tournament of Hearts|Scott Tournament of Hearts]], the women's championship.<ref name=1996Scott>Soudog's Curling History Site. [http://soudogcurling.tripod.com/STOH/1996.html 1996 Scott Tournament of Hearts]. Retrieved March 23, 2006.</ref> It gained acceptance and in 2005 the [[World Curling Championships]] started using it, but it has not yet been adopted in curling at the [[Olympic Games]].
The format is used in the [[Indian Premier League]] cricket tournament since 2011.<ref>[[Indian Premier League]]</ref>
The format has also been used in some much lower-key, internet gaming events, such as chess<ref name=Chess>Fischer Random Chess Email Club. [http://frcec.chess960.info/FischerCup.htm FRCEC's Annual Championship Tournament] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060110081449/http://frcec.chess960.info/FischerCup.htm |date=2006-01-10 }}. Retrieved March 23, 2006.</ref> and backgammon.<ref name=Backg>New Horizons Backgammon. [http://www.citlink.net/~stormygal/superleague.html New Horizon Ladder Super League] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040803035544/http://www.citlink.net/~stormygal/superleague.html |date=2004-08-03 }}. Retrieved March 23, 2006.</ref>
==Format== The system requires teams to be [[ranking|ranked]] in some way, as the top two teams have an advantage over the bottom two. This is usually accomplished through a round-robin tournament, which eliminates all but the top four teams.
===Round-robin=== A standard round-robin tournament is used, in which all teams play each other once. Because the [[Triangular number|number of total games]] increases [[Quadratic growth|quadratically]] with respect to the number of teams, scheduling too many teams will result in an unwieldy number of games, particularly when there are a limited number of [[playing surface]]s ([[ice rink|curling rink]]s usually only have four [[Curling#Playing surface|sheet]]s). Therefore, the number of teams is usually capped at around a dozen; if this is not possible or desirable, teams may be separated into groups playing separate round-robins and either having the top teams combining for the Page playoff or playing separate ones in each group and having the winners play each other after.
===Page playoff system=== The system was invented in Australia in the early 1930s and adopted soon after by the Victorian Football League (now known as the Australian Football League). The top four teams advance to the playoffs, which are played over three rounds with one team being eliminated in each round. {{citation needed|date=February 2014}}
The format progresses as follows: *In Game 1, the third- and fourth-placed teams play against each other. The loser is eliminated. *In Game 2, the first- and second-placed teams play against each other. The winner qualifies directly for the final. *In Game 3, the winner of Game 1 plays against the loser of Game 2. The loser is eliminated. *Game 4 (the final) is then played between the winners of Games 2 and 3.
This system gives the top two teams a double chance, in that they can lose their first game and still go on to win the title, producing a similar though not identical effect to a [[double-elimination tournament]]. This gives the top two teams a significant advantage over the next two, since winning the title from third or fourth place requires winning one more game than winning from first or second, and also requires defeating every other team in the playoffs. Additionally, the higher ranked team in any pairing (which, in the final, is automatically the team which won Game 2) will play as the [[home team]] to provide an additional advantage; in the case of curling teams, where teams rarely play national or international tournaments at their home rink, the advantage is that the first-placed team is given the [[Curling#Last rock (or Hammer)|hammer]] (last rock) in the first end, which is a reasonable advantage between comparably skilled teams.
In the 2008 World Women's Curling championship, a fifth match was added to the format: a bronze medal playoff match, which was played between the two teams which did not qualify for the final (the losers of Games 1 and 3). This game is normally scheduled between Games 3 and 4. Previously, the bronze would have automatically been awarded to the team which lost Game 3, so this game provides a chance for the loser of Game 1 to still receive a medal. This was also introduced at the national level at the [[2011 Scotties Tournament of Hearts]] and the [[2011 Tim Hortons Brier]]. The bronze medal game was heavily criticized for being "meaningless" in part because simply winning a "medal" does not carry the same sort of prestige it does in the Olympic Games. The bronze medal game was eliminated prior to the 2018 Canadian championship curling season.
====Names of matches==== In Australia, Games 1 and 2 are known as ''Semi-Finals''; Game 3 is called the ''Preliminary Final'', and the final is known as the ''Grand Final''. To distinguish between the two Semi-Finals, which are different in nature, the match between 3rd and 4th is known either as the ''First Semi-Final'' or the ''Minor Semi-Final''; and the match between 1st and 2nd is known either as the ''Second Semi-Final'' or the ''Major Semi-Final''.
In Curling, Games 1 and 2 are usually known as the ''Page Playoffs'' (and Game 2 is usually played first, to give the higher-ranked team more rest before Game 3); Game 3 is called the ''Semi-Final'', and the final is known by that name. However, some sources, in order to distinguish between Games 1 and 2, refer only to Game 2 as a ''Page Playoff'' while referring to Game 1 as the ''Quarter-Final.''
In India, Game 1 is known as the ''Eliminator'', Games 2 and 3 are called ''Qualifiers'', and the final is known by that name.
====Examples==== '''[[1931 VFL season#Finals|1931 Victorian Football League playoffs]]'''
The first-ever use of the system was in Australia in 1931 after the Victorian Football League adopted it. The regular season ended with Geelong winning the minor premiership, followed by Richmond, Carlton and Collingwood. The [[1931 VFL season#Finals|finals]] proceeded as follows:

==Reaction== Players and fans alike have had a mixed reaction to the system. Broadcasters enjoy it as it produces one more game than the single elimination format.<ref name=LFP/>

'''Primal Scream''' is a tradition at [[Harvard University]] that forms part of the [[streaking at educational institutions]]. At midnight on the last night of reading period and before [[final exams]] begin, students [[Streaking|streak]] through the [[Harvard Yard|Old Yard]]. The streakers begin in the north end of The Yard and generally make one lap around, but the more adventurous sometimes aim for more. This is done both semesters, even during [[New England]] winters.
Some of the streakers will "dress up" in capes and masks, or [[top hat]] and [[White tie|tails]], or other costumes, but their genitalia are still exposed.<ref name=kester2012/> The walkways through which students run are lined with spectators and the [[Harvard University Band]] plays beforehand to excite the crowd.<ref name=kester2012/>
Before it became a "night when the whole student body comes together to gawk at just that"<ref name=Thompson/> it was a night with a closer association to its name. Beginning in the 1960s students would congregate in the Yard or open their windows and just yell for 10 minutes.<ref name=kester2012/> It was designed as a way to release stress.<ref name=kester2012/> By the 1990s, the streaking aspect of the evening had become prominent.<ref name=Bronner2012/> It is still designed to give stressed out students a chance to "step outside the box."<ref name=fox2004/>
The transition from yelling to streaking is unclear. Old administrators that have been at Harvard since the 1970s speak of an earlier day of adventurous streakers. Before there was streaking in the yard began the Quad Howl—streaking in what used to be old [[Radcliffe College|Radcliffe]]. These administrators of the Quad houses speculate that the change from the Quad to the Yard, which happened during their time, was because the narrow pathways of the Quad could not accommodate the increasing multitudes of people with an urge to get naked in public. The natural choice was to go join those in the Yard, giving them something to get excited about.
A small tradition of Quad Howl continues today: after each Primal Scream, a few Quad residents return to the Quad for a naked lap there. Another related tradition is the Lingere Study Break where undergraduates in Lamont Library strip off their clothes, piece by piece, in front of hundreds of other students studying.<ref name=Bronner2012/><ref name=fox2004/>
While the records are not entirely clear, it appears that when Charles Adams, son of [[John Adams]] and brother of [[John Quincy Adams]], was a student at Harvard, he and a few friends were disciplined for getting drunk and streaking naked across the Yard. He was later readmitted.<ref name=kester2012/><ref name=adams/>
Thursday, December 11, 2014 at 12:00 midnight marked the first time that students ran the naked lap in a clockwise direction. The tradition of the naked lap has been to start outside of Hollis Hall and then take off initially running west around the Old Yard, counterclockwise. However, [[Black Lives Matter]] protesters gathered and linked arms just west of Hollis blocking the traditional path. A bit past midnight students decided to break tradition and run the naked lap clockwise in order to avoid the protesters and complete the lap.{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}}
